site_title: Connecting clients with photographers
summary: AirClick.co connects clients with photographers after founder Christopher Chong exited Groupon Singapore with $24 million, prompting early retirement.

site_title: Cross over to Suzuki
summary: Suzuki has introduced the S-Cross, a compact crossover aimed at the European market. The vehicle features a 1.6-litre naturally aspirated engine, seven-step continuously variable transmission, and four-wheel-drive capability. It offers four driving modes, including all-wheel-drive for improved traction. The S-Cross boasts a spacious interior, generous boot size, and high equipment level, including seven airbags and a panoramic sunroof. Priced from $109,900, the S-Cross is expected to revive interest in the Suzuki brand.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds (June 30, 2014)
summary: Singapore's OCBC Bank announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, taking over as the incoming CEO. This move comes amid a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are collaborating to deepen green and transition finance efforts. Tan Teck Long's appointment is seen as a significant shift in OCBC's leadership, with his background at DBS.

site_title: Alpha Bank to securitise 1b euros of loans: sources
summary: Alpha Bank plans to securitize €1 billion of shipping loans, with US bank Citi arranging the deal, in one of the first European asset-backed deals in years. The transaction aims to raise €500 million, providing funding for new loans and supporting Greece's economic recovery. The move is part of efforts to revive the European asset-backed market, which has struggled since the financial crisis. The bonds will have a five-year maturity and be privately placed.

site_title: Staying on top of new standards
summary: CPA Australia, a leading accounting body, is addressing the growing complexity of financial reporting and the need for accountants to continually upgrade their skills. With new financial reporting standards and increasing demands for greater transparency, the organization is providing education, training, and technical support to its 7,500 members in Singapore. CPA Australia emphasizes the importance of continuing professional development (CPD) to stay updated, with a minimum of 120 hours of CPD required over a three-year period to maintain CPA status. The organization aims to help its members remain relevant in the evolving business environment.

site_title: China cracks down on illegal golf courses
summary: China has ordered the demolition of at least 5 golf courses built after a 2004 ban, with the remaining courses converted into parks or tea plantations. Authorities aim to educate developers who have ignored the ban, following public shaming from the national auditor of two state-run enterprises. The demolitions serve as a warning and demonstrate the government's efforts to crack down on illegal golf course construction, with some courses being repurposed as eco-friendly spaces.

site_title: Market cap up 6.2% y-o-y
summary: Singapore's stock market rose 6.2% year-over-year, driven by banks and property firms, for its second consecutive quarter. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 1.2% in June due to the World Cup, but analysts expect blue chips to extend their gains in the second half. Mergers and acquisitions remain a key theme, with valuations boosted by companies' capital and investors' willingness to pounce. Analysts predict a rangebound second half, with targets ranging from 3,255.67 to 3,480 for the STI.

site_title: Working conditions not behind Little India riot
summary: The Committee of Inquiry (COI) into the 2013 Little India riot found that migrant workers' employment and living conditions were not the cause of the unrest, but rather a fatal accident and misperceptions about the response. Three other factors contributed to the escalation of the riot: a desire for "street-justice," alcohol intoxication, and lapses in the police response. The COI believes there is "room for improvement" in the treatment of foreign workers, but overall, the police response was effective.

site_title: Penalties still fairest way to break deadlock
summary: Brazil narrowly escaped elimination from the World Cup after a 1-1 draw with Chile that went to a penalty shootout. The game ended 1-1 at the end of extra time, with Chile's Mauricio Pinilla missing a last-gasp shot. The penalty shootout marked the first of the tournament and Brazil's victory keeps them in the competition.

site_title: Where the man in the street can hold a gig
summary: EventNook, a Singapore-based platform, allows small event organizers to easily create event websites, collect guest registration details, and sell tickets. Founded by Kyaw Lin Oo in 2011, the platform charges a 2.5% cut of ticket sales plus 30 cents per attendee for ticketed events. In contrast, Peatix, a Japanese company, offers a holistic mobile solution for event organizers, with a 2.9% cut of ticket sales plus 99 cents per attendee. Both platforms cater to niche event organizers, aiming to make event planning more accessible and user-friendly.

site_title: Temasek Holdings opens new US office
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment company, has opened a new US office in New York City. The company's chairman, Lim Boon Heng, sees the move as a step into the emerging digital future and a way to engage with the digital world. The office opening is also seen as a "fun exercise" to open minds to the potential of digital currencies, as staff recently participated in a company-wide Bitcoin experiment. This move marks Temasek's expansion into the US market.

site_title: Cheap power set to attract Asian tech companies to Arctic circle
summary: Asian tech companies, including those from China, Korea, and Southeast Asia, are expected to set up data centers near the Arctic circle due to the region's low power prices, following Google and Facebook's lead. The Nordic region is expected to experience a record electricity glut, meeting the growing demand for server halls that will require over 500 terawatt-hours of power by 2025. Energy use in Southeast Asia is predicted to increase by 80% by 2035, further fueling the trend.

site_title: MAS 'encouraging' rating of bonds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is encouraging the issuance of more rated bonds in Singapore to promote transparency and deepen the city's capital markets. This move is part of the regulator's efforts to deepen the business and increase market activity.

site_title: Neymar has his passionate groupies, the 'Neymarzetes'
summary: Brazilian soccer star Neymar has gained a massive following known as "Neymarzetes," with thousands of fans worldwide, particularly in Brazil and Europe. His influence has led to a phenomenon dubbed "Neymarmania," with his face appearing in advertisements and television commercials. His fans, mostly young girls, idolize him, with one fan saying "Neymar is first comes God, then family and then Neymar." The Brazilian forward's popularity has reached unprecedented levels, with fans eagerly following his every move.

site_title: CAD reorganises and beefs up resources to combat new financial crime threats
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has reorganized and strengthened its resources to combat financial crimes, both domestically and internationally. The Financial Police, as they now prefer to be known, aim to address the increasing complexity and scale of financial crimes. CAD director Tan Boon Gin stated that sub-specializing in thematic areas is necessary to address the evolving threats. The reorganization is part of the department's efforts to better equip itself to deal with the new challenges posed by financial crime.

site_title: Restaurant-bar fired up for the big time
summary: A Singapore restaurant, Foc, is set to launch its new menu, "Thevar 2.0," offering mod-Indian cuisine in a modern light.

site_title: DBS CEO baffled over US stock market
summary: DBS Bank CEO Piyush Gupta expressed confusion over the US stock market, despite its recent strong performance and market talk of strong growth. The S&P 500 index is near 2,000 points, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average is near 17,000 points, but data suggests a contraction in the first quarter. Gupta stated he is "quite confused" about the US market, highlighting the discrepancy between market expectations and actual data.

site_title: May loans growth could signal battle for deposits
summary: Singapore's loan growth surged 1.1% in May, outpacing deposit growth for the second consecutive month, sparking concerns about deposit competition and funding costs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported $598 billion in Singapore-dollar loans, a 1.5% increase from April, with business loans driving the growth. However, the deposit base has shrunk for two months, reaching $537 billion in May, and the loan-to-deposit ratio reached a record 111% in May, prompting banks to focus on retaining deposits ahead of Basel III liquidity ratios kicking in next year.

site_title: IPS Securex making Catalist debut
summary: IPS Securex Holdings Limited, a security products and solutions provider, made its Catalist debut after its initial public offering (IPO) was fully subscribed. The IPO raised $4.2 million and $2.7 million in gross and net proceeds, respectively. The company's shares are priced at $0.35 each, representing 16% of its enlarged share capital. IPS Securex aims to expand its business in Singapore and Asia-Pacific, driven by rising demand for security products and solutions.

site_title: MyRepublic a MyHeadache for Big 3 telcos?
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean broadband upstart, has announced ambitions to become the country's fourth full-fledged telco and offer unlimited mobile data bundles. The firm's CEO, Malcolm Rodrigues, believes MyRepublic can build and operate infrastructure at a fraction of the cost of established players like SingTel, StarHub, and M1. MyRepublic plans to raise $300 million in funding and avoid becoming a listed firm to maintain flexibility. Analysts warn that MyRepublic's business model may face challenges, including the potential for customers to hog bandwidth and the need for spectrum and regulatory support.

site_title: CitySpring in JV to develop and lease data centre
summary: CitySpring Infrastructure Trust is forming a joint venture with Shimizu Corporation to develop and lease a data centre in Singapore. The joint venture, which will hold a 51% stake, aims to deepen CitySpring's presence in telecommunications infrastructure. The data centre will have four floors for data centre halls and one floor for office space, and is expected to be completed at a total cost of $130 million. The project is part of CitySpring's strategy to develop and acquire a portfolio of data centres in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Libya's biggest oil port may reopen in Aug
summary: Libya's largest oil-export terminal, Es Sider, may reopen in August after the country's new Parliament takes office, according to a rebel group's spokesman. The port, along with Ras Lanuf, was occupied by the rebels in July 2013 to demand an oil-revenue sharing agreement. An agreement was reached in April to hand over control of two ports in exchange for amnesty and salaries for defectors. The new Parliament's meeting coincides with the end of Ramadan, and a deal to reopen the remaining two ports is expected, boosting Libya's oil production and potentially easing the price of Brent crude.

site_title: Software-defined entities riding the new wave
summary: Eric Goh, managing director of EMC Singapore, predicts a paradigm shift in the IT industry, driven by four trends: mobile, cloud computing, Big Data, and social networking. He calls this the "third platform" of IT, requiring a foundation of security, privacy, and trust. Software-defined enterprises will leverage software to build new applications and harness new data sources, driving structural changes to their advantage. This shift promises to be both disruptive and rich in opportunity for companies, IT professionals, and vendors.

site_title: MNCs see global tax risks increasing
summary: Multinational companies (MNCs) globally face increasing tax risks over the next two years, with 85% of surveyed tax and finance executives expressing concern. A lack of coordination between governments is a particular issue, creating the possibility of double taxation. The EY report, "Bridging the Divide," found that four-fifths of respondents worried about growing tax risks. MNCs, including those in Singapore, are concerned about the impact on their operations and profitability.

site_title: Record high foreigners buying Australian homes
summary: Australia approved a record A$24.9 billion in foreign home purchases by foreigners in the nine months to March 31, a 93% jump from the same period last year. This represents 13% of total turnover, with 78% of purchases being new properties. The Australian parliament is conducting an inquiry into foreign buying of domestic real estate amid concerns about unaffordable housing for local buyers, with dwelling prices rising 10.7% to a median A$545,000 in the 12 months to May 31.

site_title: Micro-organisms in your pills up next: scientist
summary: A US biotech entrepreneur, Stephen Turner, says discoveries in the microbiome could lead to commercialization of health supplements containing micro-organisms, benefiting biotech stocks. Microbiome supplements could aid oral health by introducing specific bacteria to kick out disease-causing bacteria. Recent successes include defeating the hospital superbug Clostridium difficile with fecal bacteria transplant. Turner's company, Pacific Biosciences, is focusing on improving DNA sequencing machines, which have seen a 50% rise in the Nasdaq Biotechnology exchange-traded fund in the last year.

site_title: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive
summary: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive, which took place on June 27, 2014, raised funds for various charitable causes. The event, organized by BT and Coca-Cola, aimed to support disadvantaged children and families worldwide. Although the article does not provide further details on the charity drive's outcome or impact, it highlights the partnership between two major brands to make a positive difference in the community.

site_title: Testing women for heart artery disease
summary: Women with heart artery disease often go undiagnosed due to non-specific symptoms, leading to higher death rates and complications. A new American Heart Association (AHA) Consensus Statement recommends non-invasive diagnostic testing for women, considering factors such as age, risk factors, and symptoms. The statement suggests using risk scoring systems, such as the AHA's new risk scoring system, and choosing tests like treadmill stress tests, stress echocardiography, or MRI scans, which have lower radiation exposure. For symptomatic women, a CT scan of the heart arteries may be an option if radiation dose is kept below 3 mSv.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: JTC Corporation unveiled new industrial buildings to boost SME productivity. Singapore's white-collar crime police underwent its largest reorganization in over a decade. Economists expect a "market-moving" week in the US with major stock indices potentially setting record highs. Companies fear increased global tax risks due to government coordination issues. Retail investor interest in the stock market surged, with over 68,000 new CDP accounts opened in the past year. The Malaysian economy is expected to maintain growth this year, while Western nations are vying for deals in India's opening arms sector.

site_title: Immigrants boosting US housing sales
summary: US housing sales have been boosted by immigration, particularly from Mexico, Nigeria, and Turkey, with Dayton, Ohio, seeing a 97% increase in housing sales last year compared to the national rate. The decline in immigrants granted US residency has hindered the nation's real estate recovery, with immigrants accounting for 10% of all home sales and 15% of first-time purchases. The US is missing the sales jolt provided by immigration, with the number of immigrants granted residency hitting a nine-year low.

site_title: JTC nudging SMEs towards increased productivity
summary: JTC Corporation is introducing new industrial premises that aim to increase productivity among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by encouraging them to outsource non-core services. The new facilities, such as the JTC Food Hub, will feature shared integrated services, including logistics and warehousing, to help businesses redesign their processes and enjoy economies of scale. JTC CEO Png Cheong Boon believes that SMEs are more open to change when faced with growth opportunities and limited resources, and the agency is stepping up efforts to provide innovative spaces and support the transformation of industries.

site_title: Why equities remain the flavour of the day
summary: US markets remain calm as volatility nears record lows, with some market watchers concerned about inflation triggering an earlier interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Despite concerns, analysts remain confident in equities due to historical data showing it's not the first rate hike that kills a bull market. Inflation is currently below the 4% mark, and investors are choosing to keep their money in equities due to low cash yields. However, geopolitical risks, such as tensions in the South China Sea, may pose a hidden threat to the market.

site_title: Ikea opens first city-centre store in Hamburg
summary: Ikea, the world's largest home-furnishings retailer, has opened its first city-centre store in Hamburg, Germany, in a pilot project targeting urban dwellers who prefer to shop locally. The 80 million euro store, located in the Altona district, will cater to 150,000 potential customers within a three-kilometre radius, with an average of 4,000 customers per day. The store offers a unique shopping experience, with a large glass front and a bike-sharing program, and aims to break new ground in Ikea's largest market.

site_title: Google aims to put Android in everything you do
summary: Google aims to make its Android mobile software ubiquitous across various devices, including smartwatches, cars, and TVs, to provide a seamless experience for consumers. The new version of Android, dubbed L, will feature 3-D technologies, animations, and improved privacy tools. Google's goal is to expand its software foundation as a digital gatekeeper, connecting devices and services to retain consumers. The move aims to counter rival companies like Apple and Amazon, which are also pushing to integrate their services and devices.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust aiming to raise up to $782m from IPO
summary: Accordia Golf Trust, Singapore's first golf business trust, is set to raise up to $782 million from its initial public offering on the Singapore Exchange. The offering consists of 782 million units at a price range of 97 cents to $1 per unit, offering an illustrative annual distribution per unit yield of 8.8 to 9.1 per cent. The funds will mainly be used to fund the acquisition of its initial portfolio, which includes 89 golf courses across Japan. Trading is expected to begin on August 1.

site_title: A property alliance to take on the big boys
summary: Four mid-sized property agencies in Singapore - SLP International, OrangeTee, HSR International, and Dennis Wee Realty - have formed an alliance called Project Alliance Group (PAG) to rival the two largest players, ERA Realty and PropNex Realty. The alliance, effective immediately, will focus on marketing local residential projects and has a combined strength of nearly 6,000 agents. The four agencies will share resources, training, and commissions, with the managing member receiving a larger commission. The move aims to address the shrinking pool of buyers in the market, but the two largest players, ERA and PropNex, are not concerned, citing existing market preferences and potential teething problems.

site_title: Outgoing chairman who transformed SBF
summary: Tony Chew, outgoing chairman of the Singapore Business Federation, has stepped down after three consecutive terms, marking the end of his six-year tenure. During his time, SBF achieved significant milestones, including strengthening ties with trade associations, boosting membership, and launching a foundation to encourage businesses to give back to society. Chew attributes SBF's success to the support of others, including numerous members who contributed their time, resources, and expertise to various initiatives.

site_title: How to attract and keep #GenMobile
summary: Aruba Networks reports that a new generation of tech-savvy workers, labeled as #GenMobile, is entering the workforce, requiring enterprises to design mobile networks that allow instant access from anywhere. A recent Asia-Pacific survey found that #GenMobile employees expect employers to accommodate their preferred mode of working, including flexible work arrangements and mobile device support. To address these demands, CIOs and IT managers need to improve network, security, and support systems for personal devices, and adjust performance measurement to prioritize goal-driven behavior over location and time.

site_title: OCBC gets requisite nods for Wing Hang takeover
summary: OCBC announced that all regulatory approvals have been received for its $4.95 billion acquisition of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank. The deal is subject to finalization of conditions and has been given the green light by regulators in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Macau. Moody's Investors Service has maintained its review for downgrade of OCBC's debt ratings, pending completion of the acquisition. The transaction is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust IPO units at 88 cts each
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) is set to list on the Singapore Exchange, with 185.1 million stapled securities offered at 88 cents each. The Reit has a potential acquisition pipeline through right of first refusal, which could double its portfolio and increase its asset value. FHT expects a distribution yield of 6.9% for the forecast period and 7% for the projection year. The company has a gross debt of $729 million, with an initial gearing ratio of 41.7%. Moody's has assigned a provisional Baa2 credit rating with a stable outlook, citing FHT's good revenue mix and income stability.

site_title: Perfection in simplicity
summary: Celebrated chef Simon Rogan has faced intense pressure since opening his London restaurant Fera, with critics questioning the "corporate" surroundings and accusing him of "selling out" after taking over Gordon Ramsay's Claridge's restaurant. Despite initial lukewarm reception, Rogan remains confident, citing the success of his flagship L'Enclume and the demand for his locavore-inspired cuisine. Fera's menu is designed to cater to London's fast-paced diners, with a focus on simplicity and showcasing the quality of locally sourced ingredients. Rogan aims to prove Fera's success and prove himself as a top chef in London.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: OCBC's offer for Wing Hang Bank is set to close on July 29 after satisfying all pre-conditions. Jasper Investments reported consecutive pre-tax losses for three years, putting it at risk of being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watchlist. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2.

site_title: Sentosa condos feel the blues
summary: Sentosa condominium units have seen a decline in resale prices, with about two in five units selling at a loss in the past year. According to data, 31 units have changed hands at six Sentosa projects, with 10 reselling at a loss. Volatility in the market is attributed to the single-digit number of transactions each month. Experts suggest that owners are struggling to find tenants, securing high rental rates, or managing loan repayments, leading to a decision to liquidate their units.

site_title: Economists expecting 'market-moving' week
summary: Economists expect a "market-moving" week with key reports on jobs, pending home sales, and carmaker sales. The June jobs report, released Thursday, will determine the pace of economic growth, with analysts seeking data that corroborates a 3% growth rate. A strong jobs report could lead to higher interest rates, negatively impacting stock prices. The Fed is already considering rate hikes, and traders will closely watch data for signs of hotter-than-expected growth. A "Goldilocks" week, where data is neither too hot nor too cold, could set new record highs for major US stock indices.

site_title: Popular full-year profit down 54.5%, revenue up
summary: Popular Holdings reported a 54.5% drop in full-year net profit to $10.6 million, despite a 5.3% increase in revenue to $552 million. The decline was attributed to lower gross profit margins and higher administrative and operating expenses. The group saw revenue growth across all divisions, but earnings per share decreased to 1.3 cents from 2.79 cents. Popular remains cautious of the property sector and announced a dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: Affordability of MediShield Life premiums will not be an issue: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assures that MediShield Life premiums will not be an issue due to affordability, as costs will be within each person's Medisave contributions. The highest premium increase, $355 a year, will be for those turning 76-78 years old, making the new rate $1,130. Lee praises the MediShield Life Review Committee for its work and ensures that the scheme will provide better protection against large medical bills.

site_title: 0.5ha Tuas industrial site triggered for sale
summary: A 0.5-hectare industrial site in Tuas, Singapore, has been triggered for sale with a committed bid price of at least $3,527,300, equivalent to $65.5 per square foot. The site, with a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.0, has a 20-year tenure and is zoned for Business-2 development. Experts expect 5-10 bids, with the top bid potentially reaching $85-$110 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Challenging task weaning employers off group plans
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life Review Committee suggests improving corporate tax incentives or providing grants to encourage employers to switch to portable medical benefits. The transition is challenging due to group hospitalization and surgical insurance plans being more attractive to employees and employers, particularly those with younger and healthier employee profiles. The committee's recommendations aim to make portable coverage more appealing, including a standard Integrated Shield Plan and government incentives.

site_title: Flat week for trades, buybacks
summary: Trading activity among Singapore Exchange directors was flat from June 23 to 27, with 26 purchases worth $2.56 million and 13 disposals valued at $740,000. Buyback activity was also flat, with eight companies posting 31 repurchases worth $7.97 million. Significant corporate shareholder trades included Chosen Holdings' buybacks and Fragrance Group's director purchases, while substantial shareholder sales were seen in CapitaLand, The Straits Trading Company, and CNMC Goldmine. Notable trades included Chosen Holdings' 269,000-share purchase at 14.1 cents each and Fragrance Group's 3 million-share buy at 23 cents each.

site_title: World Cup leaves traders on the bench
summary: Singapore's stock market, represented by the Straits Times Index (STI), saw a record low in average daily trading volumes during the 2014 World Cup, with volumes falling by 36% compared to the same period in previous years. The low trading volumes coincided with a decline in global stocks, but traders who took a break during the World Cup missed out on significant gains in the past two tournaments, with an average return of 4.3% and 4.6% respectively. Experts say the World Cup's impact on trading volumes is likely limited to the short-term.

site_title: US finally embraces soccer's charms
summary: The US has finally embraced soccer, with record viewership and interest in the World Cup. A record 25 million viewers watched the US take on Portugal, and the country's soccer fans are expected to continue growing. The sport has joined the Big Four American sports leagues, alongside the NFL, MLB, NBA, and NHL. While not all Americans have joined the World Cup party, the sport's popularity is undeniable, with close to four million young players and a growing domestic league, Major League Soccer, which has secured a $720 million television rights deal.

site_title: H1 syndicated loan value for Asia-Pac ex-Japan slips 2.4%
summary: The value of syndicated loans in Asia-Pacific excluding Japan decreased 2.4% to US$207 billion in the first half of 2014, despite a 12.5% increase in loan numbers. China saw a 40% drop in loan value to US$30.9 billion, mainly due to infrastructure projects. Hong Kong's loan value rose 48% to US$44.8 billion, driven by large financing projects. South-east Asia's loan value fell 15% to US$40.3 billion, with Singapore's syndicate loan values reaching US$24 billion.

site_title: Asset intensive firms turn to IT to squeeze more value
summary: Asset-intensive firms, including corporations and governments, are turning to IT to optimize heavy assets and increase value. The proposed Singapore bus sector overhaul highlights this issue, as the government and operator must reassess their roles and assets to protect shareholder value. This shift towards IT-driven efficiency is a response to decades of investments in enterprise resource planning, aiming to squeeze more value from physical assets like infrastructure and equipment. The goal is to improve productivity and cash flow, while also enhancing shareholder value.

site_title: West Coast port labour talks running out of time
summary: US retailers anxiously await a contract resolution for 20,000 West Coast port workers, with peak shipping season approaching. The six-year contract expires on July 1, and negotiations may extend into mid-July. Key issues include rising healthcare costs and the use of outside contract labor. A breakdown in negotiations in 2002 resulted in a 10-day lockout, costing the US economy $1 billion a day. The National Retail Federation estimates a 10-day work stoppage would cost $2.1 billion per day and result in 169,000 job losses.

site_title: Airbus, Jeddah bank launch Islamic aircraft leasing fund
summary: Airbus and the Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank (IDB) have launched a syariah-compliant aircraft leasing fund, targeting US$5 billion in financing for Airbus aircraft. The fund aims to cater to growing demand from airlines in the Middle East, Asia, and Africa, with Gulf airlines such as Etihad, Emirates, and Qatar Airways being key beneficiaries. The partnership will help Airbus edge out rival Boeing in the fast-growing commercial airline market, with the fund using a 4-to-1 mix of debt and equity.

site_title: Continental shift
summary: The Bentley Continental GT Speed Convertible is a high-performance, luxurious car with a 6.0-liter twin-turbo W12 engine producing 625 horsepower. It features an 8-speed automatic transmission, permanent all-wheel drive, and a refined interior with diamond-stitched upholstery. The GT Speed Convertible accelerates effortlessly, with a top speed of 325 km/h, and offers a comfortable driving experience despite its large size. However, it can experience buffeting when driven with the top down, and certain road surfaces may elicit a small wobble.

site_title: Great Eastern and shareholders unfazed by CEO's resignation
summary: Great Eastern Holdings chairman Norman Ip's predecessor, Chris Wei, resigned as CEO after less than three months, citing personal reasons to join rival Aviva plc. Ip will assume an executive role until a replacement is found. Despite the leadership change, Great Eastern stated that its business remains on track and in steady hands. The company's core business fundamentals are sound, and it is well-placed to build on its good business momentum. Ip has been on the board since 2010 and shares Great Eastern's core values. The company's shares slipped marginally following the news.

site_title: Penny stocks, takeover talks help traders in a quiet market
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a quiet week with the Straits Times Index rising 0.4% to 3,271.05. Turnover dipped below $1 billion, with many second- and third-line stocks performing well, particularly those with takeover talks or announcements. Adventus, STATS ChipPAC, and PNE Micron saw significant gains, while RH Petrogas fell 17% after its takeover talks fizzled out. The market's lack of reaction to the US GDP contraction may be due to expectations of artificially depressed interest rates.

site_title: Suit yourself
summary: Grooms-to-be are increasingly taking charge of their wedding attire, veering away from traditional one-piece suits. Bespoke menswear labels like PIMABS and The Assembly Co offer tailored packages, starting from $1,450 and $599, respectively. These labels cater to grooms with specific style preferences, creating unique outfits for their big day. While some grooms still require guidance, many are taking the initiative to ensure their attire reflects their personality. Experts emphasize the importance of comfort and individuality in wedding attire, with some even creating bold, one-of-a-kind designs.

site_title: NMP Teo Siong Seng is SBF's new chairman
summary: NMP Teo Siong Seng has taken over as chairman of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF), succeeding Tony Chew after 12 years. 21 new council members, including SGX chief Magnus Bocker, joined the federation. Teo aims to increase the SBF's reach to external markets, support SMEs, and foster ties with trade associations and business chambers. He succeeds Chew, who stepped down after serving a maximum of three consecutive two-year terms.

site_title: Robust demand for office space in Q2
summary: Singapore's office property market saw a surge in demand in Q2, with a 99.4% occupancy rate in the Shenton Way/Tanjong Pagar micro-market. Strong demand from various industries led to higher rents, with rent growth below 3.5%. Existing landlords are expected to gain bargaining power due to a limited pipeline of new office projects until 2016, supporting rental rate growth.

site_title: Carving their own niche
summary: Paul Longworth, former executive chef of Au Petit Salut, is opening his own restaurant, Rhubarb, in August with former colleague Jerome Desfonds and Au Petit Salut owner Alice Low-Ang. The three will operate independently, offering a more intimate dining experience with a focus on fine dining and experimental cuisine. Rhubarb will seat 30 on the ground floor and 16 upstairs, with a menu featuring hints of Longworth's classical French training and love of fruit. The restaurant aims to provide a unique experience without following trends, with a focus on quality and experimentation.

site_title: Crafted menu to warm the heart
summary: Local restaurant Pluck has been praised for its down-to-earth hospitality and deliberate lack of a theme. The reviewer notes the establishment's spunk in its approach. No specific events or conclusions are mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Big-belly Boeings blunt cargo-jet demand
summary: Boeing's freighter sales have stalled due to carriers shifting less-urgent deliveries to the cargo holds of Boeing 777 jetliners. The 777's spacious cargo bay is squeezing out older freighters, with sales of Boeing's 777F variant surpassing four-engine 747-8 jumbos. This shift, accelerated by high oil prices and the global recession, has led to a capacity glut in the airfreight market. Boeing needs both its major freighter offerings to flourish to avoid production cuts, with a backlog of 21 orders for the 747-8F variant.

site_title: Thank you for the passion, Brasil!
summary: A British traveler recounts his 12-day father-son adventure at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, focusing on the experience rather than England's performance. They visited Rio, Sao Paolo, and Belo Horizonte, attending five games and exploring tourist attractions. The trip was marked by a lighthearted, non-competitive attitude, as the England fan sang "England's Going Home" during a game. The writer emphasizes the importance of approaching the trip with an open mind and a broader sense of adventure.

site_title: Delivery of big liftboat lifts Triyards' record
summary: Triyards Holdings, a Singaporean company, has handed over a 450-foot self-elevating unit (SEU) to a unit of Ezion Holdings after a 20-month and $90 million project. The SEU is one of the world's largest liftboats and marks a crucial point for Triyards, increasing its status in the SEU space. The delivery widens the firm's net for capturing more clients, predominantly in the oil and gas sector, and follows industry data showing huge market potential in non-traditional markets, with 179 SEUs available.

site_title: Shares up as Ying Li ropes in China Everbright
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate's shares surged 14% as the company proposed to issue new shares and perpetual convertible securities to China Everbright Limited for $284 million. The deal will allow Ying Li to acquire more land and expand, with China Everbright intending to be a long-term investor. The transaction will be completed in two phases, with Ying Li's founder seeing his stake diluted to 35.8% after the deal. The deal aims to reduce refinancing risk and increase net gearing to 15%.

site_title: NUS price index for private homes up 0.8% in May
summary: NUS reported a 0.8% month-on-month increase in the Overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) in May, marking the first gain after nine consecutive months of declines. The increase was attributed to active sales in the primary market, but experts predict a potential dip in June due to the school holidays and World Cup. The data shows mixed trends, with some regions and unit sizes experiencing price increases, while others saw declines. The year-on-year drop in the SRPI was 6%, with smaller units showing a smaller decline of 3.1%.

site_title: US Marines resume F-35B flights
summary: The US Marine Corps has resumed flights of its F-35B jets after a fire on an Air Force F-35A jet, which had been suspended due to the discovery of engine pieces at an Air Force base. The Marine Corps will continue to deploy to the UK next month, despite concerns raised by the fire. The Air Force is investigating the cause of the fire and has suspended flights of F-35A jets. The F-35B jets flew from Arizona to Maryland on Friday, where they will be readied for trans-Atlantic flights.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Jackspeed Corp sold its Loyang factory for $6.5 million as part of efforts to redeploy capital efficiently. Meanwhile, ICP acquired a stake in an Australian coal firm for A$3 million. The article also covers various business news, including a potential fee hike for London's Heathrow airport, an Indonesian graft case, and the upcoming retirement of OCBC CEO Helen Wong, who will be succeeded by Tan Teck Long.

site_title: Fifa hands Suarez 9-match suspension for biting opponent
summary: Uruguay star Luis Suarez was suspended for 9 matches and banned from all football activity for 4 months for biting Italian defender Giorgio Chiellini during a World Cup match. Suarez was also fined 100,000 Swiss francs. The suspension is the heaviest sanction against a player in the tournament's history, according to Fifa Disciplinary Committee chief Claudio Sulser.

site_title: Boeing set to reveal 757 successor soon
summary: Boeing is set to announce a new aircraft to succeed the 757 jetliner, according to Air Astana, a Kazakh airline that is keen to purchase the plane. The new aircraft would be a medium-size jet for transcontinental travel within the US, seating 180 people in two classes and able to fly for up to nine hours. The announcement is expected soon, with Air Astana seeking deliveries starting in 2017 to replace ageing planes. The move aims to fill a gap in Boeing's roster of new jets between the 737 Max and the 787 Dreamliner.

site_title: Huawei sees major potential in the non-telco business
summary: Huawei sees significant potential in its non-telco business, particularly in the enterprise sector, which is expected to play a major role in the company's future. The enterprise segment, which was introduced in 2011, has grown 32% globally and 50% in the South Pacific region, driven by demand for better technology. Huawei aims to compete with established players like Cisco and IBM by offering a one-stop-shop service, focusing on specific verticals where the company has existing competencies. The company plans to attack these markets with better services and prices, leveraging its heritage in the telco industry.

site_title: Dutch to face stern test from spirited Mexico
summary: The Netherlands tops Group B with three convincing victories, showcasing their strong offense and depth in the bench. Mexico, meanwhile, remains unbeaten with two wins and a draw, displaying excellent organization in defense and attack. Netherlands coach Louis van Gaal's ability to manage egos and maintain team discipline will be crucial against Mexico's spirited side. The two teams are set to face a stern test, with Netherlands' offense led by Arjen Robben potentially providing a decisive moment against Mexico's disciplined defense.

site_title: Womenomics is mere talk in Japanese society
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "womenomics" policy, aimed at increasing female participation in the workforce, has been met with criticism as sexist attitudes persist in male-dominated society. A Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly member was subjected to sexist remarks and bullying, sparking a viral online petition. Experts argue that true gender equality requires diversity, not just numerical representation. Womenomics may not address the root causes of Japan's demographic problems, which include a shrinking workforce and low birth rates, and may even be at odds with the government's goal of increasing the population.

site_title: Click with event-planning
summary: Event-planning websites like Venuerific simplify the process of booking event spaces and managing corporate events, saving time and effort. Venuerific allows users to browse and book event spaces online, reducing the need for phone calls and in-person visits. This platform streamlines the event-planning process, making it more efficient and convenient for companies to plan their annual corporate dinners and other events.

site_title: 6 local firms bag Thomson Line contracts
summary: Six local firms in Singapore have secured contracts worth $1.4 billion for the Thomson Line, accounting for 27% of major civil contracts for the sixth MRT line. The contracts include 30-kilometre long line with 22 stations, set to be completed by 2021. Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew stated that the project will increase interchange stations to 30 by 2021, enhancing the rail network's resilience and providing more travel options for commuters.

site_title: GLP beefs up plans for China, Japan, Brazil
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has raised its global development start budget for fiscal year 2015 by 38% to US$2.7 billion, with a focus on China, Japan, and Brazil. GLP plans to increase its development starts in China to 30-40% annually, up from 20-25%. The company has also secured a US$2.5 billion deal with Chinese institutions to propel its business forward. GLP's chairman, Ang Kong Hua, sees opportunities in e-commerce and believes China is just starting to tap into its logistics potential.

site_title: Bonding with staff the key to sustainable F&B success
summary: Chef Darren Farr's new restaurant, The Lokal, has found success with its comfort food and cosy atmosphere, attracting a fast following in just two weeks. Farr, who previously worked at large restaurants, credits the key to his success as bonding with his staff, who he considers like family. He prioritizes staff meals and team-building, allowing him to keep a close eye on the kitchen and ensure everything is made from scratch. Farr hopes to expand The Lokal by selling his homemade products in retail and eventually finding a central kitchen space.

site_title: Board alert for the Personal Data Protection Act
summary: The Singapore Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) came into effect on January 2, 2014, with the Do-Not-Call Registry, and the remaining rules will be implemented soon. Companies must comply with the law by implementing measures for access and correction requests, obtaining consent for data collection, and ensuring accurate data. Failing to comply can result in fines of up to $1 million or imprisonment. The board should exercise supervisory powers to ensure a robust compliance framework and assess statutory obligations.

site_title: MAS fleet plan under review, says CEO
summary: Malaysian Airline System Bhd (MAS) is reviewing its fleet plan due to the disappearance of Flight 370, which has deterred passengers and tarnished the carrier's reputation. The existing order of up to 100 jets is not impacted, but future plans may be modified, according to CEO Ahmad Jauhari Yahya. MAS had previously considered ordering jets from Airbus Group and Boeing Co.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Andy Warhol's "Warhol in China" exhibition is now open at Orchard Gateway in Singapore until July 31. The show features previously unseen photographs taken by Warhol during his 1982 trip to China, including images of the Great Wall and Forbidden City. Meanwhile, Karla Marchesi's debut solo exhibition "Here Nor There" runs from July 10 to August 3 at Chan Hampe Galleries, showcasing her monochromatic works inspired by nature and urban environments. An interactive seminar on increasing access to education for girls and women in Asia is also taking place on June 30 at Changi Village Hotel.

site_title: S'pore tops South-east Asia in deal activity
summary: Singapore topped South-east Asia in deal activity at the six-month finish line, closing 143 deals out of 255 in Malaysia, Indonesia, and the US, according to American Appraisal. The country accounted for 80% of total deals worth US$22.7 billion, led by state-owned Temasek Holdings and GIC. This marks Singapore's first time as the top spot in deal activity in South-east Asia.

site_title: Euro5 diesel to be available at Johor's BHP kiosks
summary: Singapore is making cleaner Euro5 diesel available at some BHP stations in Johor, enabling Malaysian lorries and commercial vehicles to meet the country's stricter emission standards. The new diesel will have less sulphur and is more environment-friendly, with the same subsidy as Euro2 diesel. This move may encourage the Malaysian government to speed up the introduction of higher-grade diesel nationwide, and could also boost investments in energy-efficient vehicle manufacturing, benefiting car companies like Mercedes Benz and BMW.

site_title: Reits, stapled trusts outperform market in YTD total return
summary: Reits and stapled trusts in Singapore have outperformed the market with a 9.3% year-to-date total return, surpassing the 5.98% average market return. The 31 trusts have a combined market capitalization of $62 billion and median year-to-date return of 8.4%. The top three trusts are CapitaMall Trust, Ascendas Reit, and CapitaCommercial Trust, with index weightings of 12.1%, 10.8%, and 7.8% respectively on the FTSE ST Reit Index.

site_title: PM Lee, Biden reaffirm strong bilateral ties
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with US President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, reaffirming strong bilateral ties and the US rebalancing towards Asia. They discussed China's "destabilising behaviour" in the South China Sea and the ongoing Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations. The leaders agreed to achieve an "ambitious, high-standard deal" in the TPP talks, set to be concluded later this year.

site_title: Double joy for Messi's birthday
summary: Lionel Messi scored two goals in Argentina's 2-0 win over Nigeria, securing the maximum nine points in the group stage of the World Cup. The forward now joins Brazil's Neymar as the tournament's top scorer with four goals. Argentina's unbeaten streak stands at 24 games, and they will face Switzerland in the Round of 16 next Tuesday. With striker Sergio Aguero a doubt, pressure is on Messi to lead the attack and help Argentina win their first World Cup title in 28 years.

site_title: Reforming Asian giants back on investors' radar
summary: Reports on China and India's economic struggles appear exaggerated, with investor confidence returning due to expected structural reforms in both countries. China's Big Four banks have risen 15% since March lows, and investment-grade bonds are yielding 6-8% over the next 12 months. India's twin deficits have decreased, and the rupee has stabilized. Analysts expect domestic cyclicals to benefit from reform, with opportunities in the energy and industrial sectors. However, concerns remain about China's debt and banking sector, and interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve pose a risk to markets.

site_title: 'Highly likely' jet was on autopilot: Australia
summary: Australian officials have concluded that Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 was "highly likely" on autopilot when it crashed, killing all 239 people on board. The Boeing 777 disappeared on March 8. An expert group reviewed existing information and made the determination after months of searching the Indian Ocean. The search area will now shift further south as investigators seek to uncover the cause of the disappearance.

site_title: SingTel's relationship with OTT players complicated
summary: SingTel, a Singaporean telecommunications company, is cautiously exploring partnerships with over-the-top (OTT) players like Viber and WhatsApp, aiming to become their preferred network partner. Despite wariness of OTT companies threatening traditional revenue streams, SingTel sees value in providing connectivity to OTT providers. The company has made significant digital acquisitions, spending about a quarter of its $2 billion digital acquisition fund. CEO Chua Sock Koong's pay package increased by 2.2% to $4.71 million, with a focus on performance-based bonuses.

site_title: The mobile race in developing markets
summary: Mobile payments are slow to catch up in developing markets, despite rising mobile usage. Software makers and advertisers need to adapt by supporting carrier wallets to remove friction from payment, or users will avoid paying for content. In emerging markets, mobiles are first screens, not second screens, and ad expenditure should shift to reflect this behavior. Companies from developed markets often misunderstand these differences, and mobile advertising platforms are introducing services to cater to the largely pre-paid user base, such as Vserv's SmartRewards and Jana's Marketplace. The addressable user base in emerging markets has grown significantly, with potential for continued growth, and Vserv is poised to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: CDP sees highest 12-month surge in new accounts
summary: Singapore's Central Depository (CDP) has seen its highest 12-month surge in new accounts, reaching 1.6 million members, with about half holding shares. This growth is attributed to increased retail investor interest, with 68,000 new accounts opened and 187,000 subscribers to the SGX's My Gateway e-newsletter. However, the proportion of Singaporeans invested in the stock market remains low, with only 8-10% of the population actively involved. The exchange aims to increase awareness and provide education to retail investors, partnering with TradeHero to offer a mobile market trading application and a prize money contest to learn trading with virtual money.

site_title: Carnival's adjusted profit forecast falls below market estimates
summary: Carnival Corp, the world's largest cruise operator, forecast an adjusted profit below market estimates for the third quarter, citing increased competition in the Caribbean. The company expects an adjusted profit of $1.38-$1.44 per share, below analyst estimates of $1.51 per share. Carnival attributes the decline to a surge in industry capacity in the Caribbean, leading to increased promotions and price competition. The company raised its full-year adjusted profit forecast to $1.60-$1.75 per share.

site_title: Fostering growth in e-commerce
summary: Singapore has tremendous potential for e-commerce growth due to its tech-savvy consumers, established regulations, and world-class delivery and payment infrastructure. Experts expect the trend to continue, with e-commerce platforms enabling businesses to mitigate traditional constraints and tap into global markets. The government needs to support local companies and position itself as a regional distribution hub for leading global e-commerce providers. With online retail accounting for only 1.5% of purchases in Singapore, the potential for e-commerce is considerable, particularly with the convenience of online shopping and the decline of mall experiences.

site_title: Deliveries to keep you in high spirits
summary: A 24-year-old entrepreneur, Triston Ong, has launched an online alcohol delivery service called Asherbws.com, which was inspired by his family's offline alcohol distribution business in Singapore. The platform allows customers to order a wide variety of beers, wines, and spirits with flexible delivery options. To differentiate himself, Mr. Ong offers value-added services such as wine-tasting sessions, which provide customers with a more immersive experience and appreciation for their purchases. With competitive pricing and a 10% discount for membership holders, Asherbws.com aims to capture a share of the competitive alcohol market.

site_title: LA River plan driving land prices up
summary: A US Army Corps of Engineers plan to restore the Los Angeles River to a more natural state is driving up land prices in the area. The $1 billion project aims to landscape 18 kilometers of the riverbed with grass, trees, parks, and wildlife habitats. This has attracted private investors, with some speculators already offering $88-a-square-foot for parcels of land. The restoration push has sparked concerns about gentrification, but proponents see it as an opportunity to revitalize a neglected area and create a unique waterfront experience.

site_title: Creditor gets court order to sell Anwell unit assets
summary: ANWELL Technologies' subsidiary Henan Kerry Digital Co Ltd has had 229.4 million yuan (S$46.5 million) worth of assets seized by a creditor for outstanding debts of approximately 94 million yuan. The interim management is unable to determine if remaining assets will be sufficient for manufacturing and daily operations. If the assets are sold and the group cannot continue using them, operations and financial performance will be adversely affected. An auction of the assets has been scheduled.

site_title: Vibrant's full-year profit up 11.2% on higher revenue
summary: Vibrant Group, a Singapore-based logistics company, reported an 11.2% increase in full-year net profit to $42.7 million, driven by higher revenue of 8.4% to $191.4 million. Freight and logistics revenue rose 5.9% to $172.6 million, while the financial services segment saw a 39.4% leap in revenue. Despite uncertainties in global economic conditions, the company plans to strengthen and expand its businesses. A first and final cash dividend of 0.55 cents per share was announced.

site_title: $4b lift-off for MediShield Life
summary: The Singapore government has accepted the MediShield Life Review Committee's recommendations to revamp the national health insurance scheme, which aims to balance affordable premiums with enhanced benefits. The revamped scheme will offer lifelong coverage and better protection against large hospital bills, with increased daily claim limits, lower co-insurance rates, and a higher lifetime claim amount. The government will commit $4 billion in financial support over five years, including transitional subsidies and permanent premium subsidies for lower- to middle-income households. Premiums are expected to increase, but the government will introduce measures to help Singaporeans cope, including subsidies and Medisave top-ups.

site_title: Correction
summary: A correction was published in a previous article, where the quotes from the Singapore Accountancy Commission's chairman were incorrectly attributed to the chairman, Michael Lim, when in fact they belonged to the SAC chief executive Uantchern Loh.

site_title: What's up at the World Cup so far
summary: The 2014 FIFA World Cup in Brazil has reached its halfway mark, with 16 teams advancing to the knockout stage. The Netherlands has emerged as the standout team, winning all three group stage games, while Costa Rica has surprised by topping their group with a 3-1 win over Uruguay and a 1-0 victory over Italy. Spain has been a major disappointment, losing to the Netherlands and Chile, and will likely miss the quarterfinals. Luis Suarez has been banned from world football for four months after biting an Italian player, while Tim Cahill scored a thrilling goal against the Netherlands.

site_title: Chan's industrial-strength irony
summary: The Schaulager museum in Basel has hosted a retrospective of Hong Kong-born artist Paul Chan, showcasing his works in a lighter tone compared to Steve McQueen's heavy pieces. Chan's exhibition features a range of pieces, including paintings, sculptures, light installations, and digital cartoons, with mischief and irony being prominent themes. The show runs at the museum, which is known for its cutting-edge design, highlighting Chan's growing reputation in the New York art scene.

site_title: Rakuten 'to buy big stake in AirAsia's Japan venture'
summary: Rakuten Inc, Japan's largest online retailer, plans to buy a major stake in a Japanese budget airline to be established by Malaysia's AirAsia Bhd. The deal, set to be announced on July 1 in Tokyo, aims to tap Japan's lucrative air market. AirAsia's Tony Fernandes will partner with Rakuten's Hiroshi Mikitani, who controls Japan's fourth-richest man. The airline will be based at Chubu airport, offering landing rights unavailable at crowded airports serving Japan's capital, potentially increasing competition among Japan's discount carriers.

site_title: More global IPOs expected in second half
summary: Global initial public offerings (IPOs) are expected to continue in the second half of 2014, driven by economic recovery and buoyant equity indices. The EY Global IPO Trends report indicates a significant uptick of IPOs from the financial, real estate, technology, and consumer products and services sectors. The first half of 2014 saw 588 deals raising $117.7 billion, a 60% increase in deal numbers and 67% increase in capital raised compared to the same period in 2013.

site_title: Pick of the Week
summary: Singapore's OPEN festival, a prelude to the Singapore International Festival of Arts (Sifa), is set to run from June 26 to July 12, featuring up to 17 days of films, performances, talks, and more. The event aims to encourage audience ownership of ideas and themes, with a focus on legacies and their impact on the present and future. The festival includes exhibitions, screenings, and talks on various themes, including violence, iconic legacies, digital legacies, and science. Ticket prices start at $35 for special performances.

site_title: Hyflux enters sale and lease-back deal for global HQ
summary: Hyflux has entered a sale and lease-back deal with Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) for its global headquarters, the Hyflux Innovation Centre, valued at $170 million. The deal will generate a $84 million divestment gain for Hyflux, which will use the funds to invest in new technology, expand membrane manufacturing, and fund infrastructure projects. Hyflux will lease back 50% of the property for 15 years, with A-Reit paying an upfront land premium of $21.2 million.

site_title: An exhausting, interminable experience
summary: The latest Transformers movie, Age of Extinction, is a predictable and excessive blockbuster that fails to deliver in terms of character development or thought-provoking dialogue. Director Michael Bay's signature style of over-the-top action sequences and sensory assault prevails, making for an exhausting and interminable viewing experience. The film's plot revolves around an alliance between humans and Autobots being dismantled, with a sinister government plot to create their own Transformers. Critics argue that the movie is a numbing, effects-driven summer blockbuster that prioritizes action over substance, leaving viewers shell-shocked and eager for more of the same.

site_title: Audemars Piguet makes major foray into art
summary: Luxury watch brand Audemars Piguet has launched the Audemars Piguet Art Commission, supporting the creation of one major artwork annually by an emerging or mid-career artist. The initiative aims to inspire art collectors and have a stimulus for understanding artists' perspectives. The company, inspired by parallels between watchmaking and art, will commission artists for future Art Basels, starting with the 2015 event. This move marks Audemars Piguet's major foray into the contemporary art scene, reflecting the brand's desire to be inspired by artists and collectors.

site_title: How MediShield Life works
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country aims to capitalize on this opportunity, with a study suggesting it can become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. In other news, the government has introduced new grants, including up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, the Minister of Manpower has advised graduates to stay calm, citing early data showing better employment rates. The government is also providing support for workers who need training, with the Singapore Business Federation offering assistance.

site_title: Get chauffeured in a luxury marque
summary: Uber, a private driver service, is now available in Singapore, offering two options: UberExec (premium cars) and UberX (lower-priced cars). The service allows users to book a car with a single button on the app, track the car's movement, and pay with their credit card. Uber's regional manager, Michael Brown, emphasizes the convenience, accountability, and safety of the service, which includes surge pricing during peak hours. The service is popular among those with disposable income seeking a private driver experience, with prices 1.5 to 2.5 times higher than regular taxis.

site_title: Healthy take on casual dining at Chiltern Firehouse
summary: Chiltern Firehouse in London, a converted fire station, has become a hotspot for celebrities and foodies alike. The hotel's trendy eatery, designed by Andre Balazs, offers a smartly curated menu by chef Nuno Mendes, with dishes such as grilled Iberico pork, mushroom pizzette, and a standout "frozen apple pannacotta". The menu's focus on fresh, punchy flavors and controlled portions has won over top London critics, but some may find it lacking in technique and style. Despite this, the restaurant's style and attitude are undeniable, making it a must-visit for those seeking a fashionable dining experience.

site_title: Hello again, Yellow Brick Road
summary: Elton John's 1973 album Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, originally recorded in Jamaica due to political unrest, has been reissued in various editions to mark its 40th anniversary. The 17-track double-album features classics like "Candle in the Wind" and "Bennie and the Jets." Producer Peter Asher aimed to re-approach the songs rather than improve them, incorporating unreleased demos and alternate mixes to showcase the album's songwriting genius. A bonus disc features covers by contemporary acts like Ed Sheeran and Fall Out Boy, introducing the album to a new generation of fans.

site_title: Japan firm plans 100b yen boost to hotel ventures
summary: Hulic Co, a Japanese real estate firm, plans to invest up to 100 billion yen (S$1.2 billion) in hotel ventures over the next five years, driven by rising inbound tourism in Japan. The company aims to acquire properties for hotel development, particularly in key locations, as the government targets 20 million inbound tourists by 2020. This move comes as foreign visitors to Japan reached a record high in April, with consumption by inbound tourists rising 31% to 1.4 trillion yen in 2013.

site_title: Korean film production group seeks Catalist listing
summary: A Korean film production group, Spackman Entertainment Group, is seeking a listing on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The group, which owns Zip Cinema and Opus Pictures, aims to raise funds to invest in films, expand via acquisitions, and set up overseas offices. The company reported a profit of US$2.6 million in FY2013, after recording a loss the previous year, and has an issued and paid-up share capital of close to S$18.2 million. The IPO and listing are expected to support the group's expansion plans and utilize funds for general working capital.

site_title: Richter's multiple perspectives
summary: Gerhard Richter's retrospective exhibition at the Beyeler Foundation in Basel, Switzerland, showcases the German artist's diverse and contradictory style, defying a single cohesive approach. From grand photo-realistic masterpieces to abstract and expressive works, visitors are confronted with seemingly contradictory elements of his practice. Richter's techniques, including scraping and squeegeeing paint, create happenstance and new compositions, while his controversial works, such as the Baader-Meinhof series, continue to shock and provoke. The exhibition, running until September 7, highlights Richter's enigmatic nature and artistic complexity.

site_title: Celebrating Singapore's best visual artists
summary: Singapore's upcoming "Singapore Eye" book will feature 75 of the country's top contemporary artists, with a four-page picture spread and brief explanations of their artistic practices. An accompanying exhibition of 25 selected artists will open at the ArtScience Museum in January 2015. The book and exhibition are part of the Eye series, which has already published books on South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Hong Kong, providing a comprehensive guide to each country's visual arts scene.

site_title: Hard-hitting double bill
summary: Singaporean playwright Han Lao Da's dystopian play "Floathouse 1001" sees the country's elderly being placed in pods that drift to sea upon death, sparking rebellion. The play, translated by Jeremy Tiang, is part of a double bill featuring "Floating Bones," a dream play questioning the senses. Director Elina Lim brings her experience to the productions, reshaping the scripts to ensure accuracy and portraying the playwright's intentions. The plays, which have not been restaged in over a decade, explore themes of overcrowding and aging, with a current resonance in Singapore.

site_title: World Cup may decide Brazil's next leader
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff's re-election bid may be bolstered by a successful World Cup, which could overshadow her opponents' criticisms of her administration's billions spent on the tournament. Despite protests and strikes, Rousseff leads her main opponent Aecio Neves in polls, with 39% of voters supporting her candidacy. A trouble-free World Cup and a Brazilian victory could reduce ammunition for her opponents, making her re-election more likely. Rousseff has promised to boost social policies and invest in public services, but faces criticism over the World Cup's budget and economic slowdown.

site_title: Here to prove she's no 'one-hit wonder'
summary: German-born artist Stefanie Hauger is showcasing her work in a solo exhibition, "New Horizons," at the UOB Art Gallery in Singapore. The exhibition features two series of her art, "Mandala" and "Moments," which demonstrate her growth as an artist since winning the 2013 UOB Painting of the Year title. Hauger aims to prove she's a serious artist, not a "one-hit wonder," and is also part of a new initiative where Painting of the Year alumni will have a dedicated space to showcase their works.

site_title: Downside risks cloud S'pore growth
summary: Singapore's economic growth faces downside risks for Q2 and 2014, as the manufacturing sector contracted for the first time since June last year. Factory output declined 2.5% in May, driven by drops in electronics and biomedical manufacturing. Private-sector economists now expect full-year GDP growth to fall short of earlier forecasts, likely lower than 2013's 3.9% expansion. This marks a surprise reversal of earlier expectations, indicating a potential slowdown in the country's economic growth.

site_title: Global Invacom licks its chops as its peers retire
summary: Global Invacom Group, a satellite equipment maker, is embarking on an acquisition campaign to capitalize on the retirement of its peers, many of whom are in their 60s. The company plans to use $15 million from its London IPO to acquire businesses, with a focus on the US, South America, and India. CEO Tony Taylor expects acquisitions to be the main focus for the next 1-2 years, with the company aiming to become the leading player in the industry.

site_title: China residential sector primed for shake-up as downturn drains cash
summary: China's residential sector is experiencing a severe cash crunch, with developers' cash to short-term debt ratios at two-year lows due to a downturn in property prices and a tightening credit market. The sector's oversupply of properties and stagnant prices have led to a decline in margins, with some developers facing financial pressures, including failed deliveries and reduced Ebitda margins. The government's crackdown on the market and increased interest rates on trust loans have exacerbated the situation, with some analysts predicting further consolidation in the sector.

site_title: Asiana crash crew 'unfamiliar with auto-throttle'
summary: The crew of an Asiana Airlines Boeing 777 that crashed into the sea wall at San Francisco International Airport in 2014 had deficient training and were unfamiliar with the auto-throttle system. They disabled the auto-throttle, thinking it would prevent a slow descent, and failed to follow procedures, leading to a highly abnormal attitude. The crew was counting on the auto-throttle to regulate speed, but it was not functioning correctly. The crash resulted in three fatalities and 291 injuries, with all four flight attendants in the rear galley being pulled from the plane when the tail broke off.

site_title: Asian art powers on in Basel
summary: Art Basel, the world's largest art fair, saw a surge in Asian art and collectors, with galleries from 21 countries selling $4 billion worth of art. Asian art gained prominence, with galleries like Long March Space and STPI selling works by prominent Asian artists like Rirkrit Tiravanija and Shinro Ohtake. Despite a decline in Asian galleries, the fair still attracted a significant number of Asian collectors, with many international galleries showcasing Asian artworks. The fair's organizers aimed to balance commerce and art, with non-commercial activities like the 14 Rooms performance art exhibition.

site_title: Music to the ears of the Pioneer Generation
summary: The Philharmonic Youth Winds will present a special concert, "Songs Our Parents Love," on Sunday at the Esplanade Concert Hall. The event is designed to be a "win-win" for both older and younger audiences, featuring familiar pop oldies from the Pioneer Generation and collaborations with local talents. The concert aims to showcase the versatility of the wind band sound while maintaining recognizable symphonic interpretations of classic songs. Tickets range from $15 to $40, with a portion of the proceeds likely benefiting the Pioneer Generation.

site_title: Gold sector to yield $500m in value-added: Yi Shyan
summary: Singapore's new gold refinery, operated by Metalor Technologies, is expected to create $500 million in value-added to the economy and 1,000 jobs by 2020. The refinery, which has a production capacity of 50-150 tonnes per year, will allow for increased cost efficiency among bullion traders in Asia, thanks to Singapore's strategic location. The refinery, which is Metalor's fifth worldwide and third in Asia, will also start producing silver products by the end of the year, benefiting from lower freight costs and faster delivery.

site_title: Less work, more play at ports, offices
summary: Brazil's main shipping ports are shutting down or operating on reduced hours during national team matches in the World Cup soccer tournament. The dock workers' union in Paranagua, Brazil's No 2 soy exporting port, has negotiated an ordinance allowing them to stop work an hour before and an hour after matches, totaling around four hours. This is unprecedented, with the port usually operating during holidays. The agreement applies to group play matches, and if Brazil advances, a new ordinance may be drawn up. Similar arrangements have been made in other ports, including Santos, where individual terminal operators decide on game-day operations.

site_title: Speculation continues as Aspial CEO ups LCD stake
summary: Aspial Corporation CEO Koh Wee Seng continues to buy shares in LCD Global Investments at prices above the 17 cents a share offer from the Lum brothers, sparking speculation of a counter-bid. Koh's stake in LCD has risen to 15.24%, fueling market talk of a competing offer or pressure to raise the bid price. The offer's closing date has been extended to July 11, and market chatter suggests Koh may make a competing offer or push the offerors to increase their bid price.

site_title: Keppel Shipyard signs conditional contract with Golar
summary: Keppel Shipyard signed a conditional contract with Golar Hilli Corporation to convert the world's first Moss LNG carrier into a floating liquefaction vessel. The deal, worth between $580 million and $700 million, is expected to be completed by the end of 2016, with the option to convert two more vessels.

site_title: China Vanke expanding overseas, in talks with strategic investors
summary: China Vanke, the country's largest residential property developer, is in talks with global investors to sell a strategic stake. The stake sale could be achieved through new shares or buying shares from the secondary market. This move aims to expand overseas and tap offshore capital markets, with Vanke chairman Wang Shi stating it will help the company's international brand and attract strategic investors. The sale is seen as a step to leverage the Hong Kong platform.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's growth is now at risk due to the manufacturing sector's contraction in May. Asian giants such as China and India are gaining investor attention. In other news, the ASEAN region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, while a low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre gambit. The US saw a decline in weekly jobless claims, and China is urging Southeast Asia to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, and Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year.

site_title: TPP will show US seriousness as an Asia-Pacific power: PM
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is a signal of the US's commitment and seriousness as an Asia-Pacific power. The TPP, involving 12 Pacific Rim countries, is nearing completion and is economically and strategically important to the US. Lee's comments came during a dialogue at the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington, highlighting the pact's significance in the region. The talks are expected to wrap up later this year.

site_title: Suarez gives Adidas moral dilemma
summary: Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez left Adidas with a World Cup dilemma after appearing to bite Italian defender Giorgio Chiellini's shoulder during a 1-0 win in Natal, Brazil. Suarez, who was banned for biting an opponent last year, ignored questions after the match. The incident has raised concerns about Suarez's behavior and sparked a moral dilemma for Adidas, a sponsor that has faced criticism for its association with the player. Suarez's actions have also led to speculation about his future with the team and his reputation in the soccer world.

site_title: First-quarter GDP falls the most in five years
summary: The US economy contracted at a 2.9% annual rate in the first quarter, the largest decline in five years, according to the Commerce Department. This revised estimate lowered growth by three percentage points since April, suggesting factors beyond the unusually cold winter may be at play. Despite the initial contraction, there are indications that the economy has since rebounded strongly.

site_title: Latin passion holds sway at the World Cup
summary: Latin American fans have dominated the World Cup, with teams from Mexico to Uruguay outplaying European rivals and creating a carnival atmosphere in Brazilian stadiums. However, their loud and rowdy behavior has caused security headaches for authorities. The tournament's organization has been praised by a sports management expert, with 300 foreign fans giving a good grade to the event's organization. Meanwhile, anti-Cup protests have dwindled, with most fans focused on celebrating the tournament rather than protesting its cost.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's proposed framework for systemically important banks is sparking regulatory cost and issues. The Monetary Authority of Singapore unveiled more details, highlighting concerns. The US economy contracted in Q1, its worst performance in five years, but growth has rebounded. Equity Plaza in Raffles Place sold for $550m, and Hyflux signed an MOU with a Mexican bank to collaborate on water projects. Align Technology set up its Asia-Pacific headquarters, and prime strata retail unit values increased due to limited supply.

site_title: Hyflux makes foray into Mexico projects
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Banco Interacciones, Mexico's leading infrastructure bank, to collaborate on water projects in Mexico. The move marks Hyflux's first foray into Latin America, with potential projects valued between US$10 million and US$150 million. The companies will work together on equity financing, institutional relations, and greenfield projects, with Hyflux aiming to bid on at least two projects this year and up to 200 projects in the next five years.

site_title: Foxconn chairman urges patience as sales slow
