The company aims to provide the best possible experience through purposeful design and complementary solutions. This move follows a similar trend of tech giants investing in innovative devices and solutions.

site_title: Tuned in to a fusion of flavours
summary: Sofitel So Singapore's in-house restaurant Xperience offers East-West fusion cuisine in a unique, high-energy environment. The restaurant's quirky menu features dishes such as foie gras and truffle siew mai, seared pork knuckle, and charcoal eggplant. While some dishes, like the lobster and scallop laksa risotto, may not sit well with those who prefer thoroughly cooked rice, others, like the roasted lamb and lentil curry, excel. Service can be slow and inexperienced, but the food's wholesome approach and pure tastiness make it a standout aspect of the hotel. Rating: 7.

site_title: Bandwidth boom and the beautiful game
summary: The 2014 World Cup in Brazil will feature a massive increase in global viewership, with 3.2 billion people watching the final game, accounting for 46% of the global population. This is a significant leap from the 1998 World Cup in France, where spectators would have consumed 2 megabytes of bandwidth if every one of them sent a text message during the match. Today, spectators in Brazil are expected to consume 12.6 terabytes of bandwidth, and this figure is predicted to be even higher for the Qatar World Cup in 2022, with spectators expected to consume 1.3 petabytes of bandwidth.

site_title: Beckham's boots up for grabs - for at least $1,250
summary: David Beckham's signed football boots, featuring his children's names, are up for auction in Singapore with a minimum bid price of $1,250. The proceeds will benefit two local charities: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The auction, part of Marina Bay Sands' Sands for Singapore festival, aims to raise $3.6 million for various designated charities. The event also includes a dinner auction on August 1, featuring performances by international ballroom dancing champions.

site_title: IPO market could stir from slumber in H2
summary: The IPO market in Singapore is expected to revive in the second half of 2014, driven by easy credit and a shift away from yield plays. Despite just two mainboard IPOs this year, which raised $735 million, bankers predict a surge in listings, with several large transactions, including those from Alibaba, WH Group, and 1MDB, expected to take the volumes higher. M&A activity is also likely to keep pace, with Singapore standing out as the top acquirer country in South-east Asia.

site_title: Startup life here begins a bit later, and after a job
summary: A survey of 102 Singapore startups found that entrepreneurs aged 35 and above are increasingly founding companies, challenging the traditional image of young, socially awkward entrepreneurs. The number of startups founded by those 35 and above has risen since 2006, with many leveraging accumulated industry knowledge to tackle unresolved issues. This trend is attributed to individuals who took "sensible" jobs, only to start their own companies later, driven by a desire to use their expertise to make a difference.

site_title: More spectrum to be freed up for broadband-type services
summary: Singapore will introduce regulation for the use of radio spectrum in TV White Space (TVWS) bands, becoming one of the first countries to do so, in November. The regulations aim to maximise spectrum use and make 180 MHz of spectrum available for wireless broadband communications. The framework will set out equipment requirements, spectrum channels, and geo-location database operations to ensure efficient use of the spectrum. The government will waive licence fees for the first two years to encourage adoption of TVWS technology, which may be used for machine-to-machine communications, smart metering, and Internet of Things applications.

site_title: 20 years on and still at the top of its game
summary: Takashimaya Singapore marked its 20th anniversary with record sales of $639 million in 2013, a 3.4% increase from the previous year. Despite challenges from competition and rising costs, the retailer credited regular store refurbishments and a unique shopping experience to its success. Its large store area, featuring a food hall and various brands, appeals to tourists and locals alike, accounting for 23% of sales. The company's ability to innovate and stay ahead of consumer lifestyles has enabled it to maintain its position as a leading department store in Singapore.

site_title: Getting to grips with genetic twists
summary: Genetic studies have revealed that 40-60% of coronary artery disease (CAD) susceptibility is inherited, with 50 genetic variants associated with an increased risk of CAD. These variants can increase CAD risk by different mechanisms independent of traditional risk factors like high cholesterol. A specific genetic variant on chromosome 9, known as 9p21, has been identified, which increases the risk of CAD by 25% for one copy and 50% for two copies. This knowledge can lead to the development of new treatment modalities targeting genetic pathways to reduce CAD risk, and may also explain why individuals with good risk-factor control can still develop significant CAD.

site_title: STI closes flat with an upward bias
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed flat, up 0.24 points at 3,293.25, despite concerns over the crisis in Iraq and its potential impact on global oil prices. Asian markets, however, showed optimism with China's Shanghai Composite gaining 0.9% and Japan's Nikkei rising 0.8%. The gains were driven by upbeat Chinese industrial output and retail sales data, which fueled optimism over the resilience of the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: A well-dressed home
summary: Fashion brands Kate Spade, Calvin Klein, Bottega Veneta, and Hermes are expanding into the lifestyle business with new collections, including stationery, gifts, home decor, and furniture. Kate Spade launched its Stationery and Gifts collection in Singapore, while Calvin Klein showcased its Home collection in an architectural installation. Bottega Veneta's home collection was launched in 2006 and is available in Singapore starting September. These brands aim to bring back the charm of writing and offer quiet luxury and elegance in home decor, appealing to existing fans and those looking to buy for friends.

site_title: Fix software front-end from back: Forrester
summary: Forrester's John McCarthy suggests companies focus on rethinking their back-end IT architecture before redesigning their software front-ends, as getting mobile right is a back-end challenge. This includes making mobile software more modular to retrieve data and work with back-end payment systems smoothly. Companies like dotcom e-tailers are giving traditional firms a run for their money by leveraging data to provide a better user experience, while traditional firms struggle with outdated systems. The industry is expected to spend $1 trillion on IT by 2017, with only 10-15% of companies doing well in providing good software.

site_title: Director sales up for 2nd week
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Singapore Exchange filings show a reversal in buying and selling trends among directors. In the week of June 9-13, 22 purchases worth $890,000 were made, down from the previous week's 24 purchases. Disposals, however, exceeded $16m, up from $1.9m the previous week. Several directors, including Anchun International's Liang Gong Zeng and UMS Holdings' Andy Luong, made significant sales. AIA Group also sold shares in Mapletree Commercial Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and Starhill Global Reit. The trend may signal a shift in market sentiment, with some analysts noting purchases by Schroders and Hiew Yoon Khong.

site_title: Fresh seafood that is just a click away
summary: The Alaska Guys, an online seafood retailer, offers fresh and frozen Alaskan king crab, salmon, halibut, and black cod for home delivery in Singapore. The business, founded by Kevin Gantner and Dean DeCuir, sources seafood from Alaska and Chile, with a focus on sustainable and high-quality products. Prices range from $62 to $120 per kg, and the duo plans to open a retail shop and supply to local restaurants as demand increases.

site_title: Fall in wholesale electricity prices worries gencos
summary: Singapore generation companies (gencos) are concerned about wholesale electricity prices falling below the cost of their natural gas feedstock, posing financial risks. Prices have stayed below $150/MWh due to oversupply from new plants and rigid gas supply contracts with "take-or-pay" clauses. Industry officials warn that this is an unsustainable situation and urge gencos to take a longer-term perspective. Gas feedstock prices are expected to rise when current PNG supply contracts expire around 2022, potentially bringing relief to the market.

site_title: 1MDB holds board meeting in Lucerne
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) held a board meeting in Lucerne, Switzerland, to discuss a 500 MW solar photovoltaic project across Malaysia, with a pilot project set to begin in 2016. The project, worth RM350 million, will be developed by a partnership between 1MDB and Washington-based DuSable Capital Management, with Tenaga Nasional as the national utility partner. The ambitious plan aims to generate electricity in various parts of the country over the next five to six years, with potential for further expansion if the pilot project is successful.

site_title: AirAsia shelves plans to purchase Mandala
summary: AirAsia has shelved plans to purchase Tigerair Mandala, citing "uncertain market conditions" and a decision not to pursue the transaction. This comes after Citilink ended talks to acquire the airline. Tiger Airways Holdings, which has been struggling with losses, is reviewing its investment in Mandala and may consider selling its 35.8% stake. Analysts believe the pullout by AirAsia and Citilink could make it harder for Tiger Airways to sell its stake, and the company may need to cut losses from other units to turn its business around.

site_title: Spain to sell 49% stake in airport operator AENA
summary: Spain's government approved the sale of a 49% stake in state-owned airport operator AENA, worth nearly 2.5 billion euros, as part of a long-delayed privatisation plan. The sale will raise billions of euros for the government, which has seen a 12% rise in its stock market this year. AENA, which manages 46 airports in Spain and abroad, has a valuation of 16 billion euros, but also carries a debt of over 11 billion euros. The 49% stake will be sold in two stages, with private investors and then the public, and AENA will remain a state-owned organisation with the government holding a majority.

site_title: Let them eat football, says Fifa
summary: Fifa has been criticized for its handling of the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, where protests and violence erupted due to the massive costs and corruption involved in the event. The construction of stadiums, many of which were built on the homes of low-income residents, led to widespread outrage and displacement. An auditor's report revealed price-gouging and inflated claims totaling US$275 million, while Fifa made a tax-free profit of US$1.1 billion. The government responded with a new anti-terror law, deploying 170,000 security men to quell the protests, resulting in 27 deaths.

site_title: Touch of class
summary: Several high-end fashion brands have launched their home furnishings collections in Singapore, including Kate Spade, Diesel by Moroso, Blumarine, Roberto Cavalli, Bottega Veneta, Hermes, Maison Martin Margiela, and Ralph Lauren. These collections feature unique designs, materials, and styles, ranging from girlish and bold to modern and quirky. The brands aim to bring their fashion sensibilities to the home decor market, with an emphasis on clean lines, elegance, and sophistication.

site_title: Shear luxury
summary: The traditional wet shave, made famous by luxury barbershops, is experiencing a resurgence in popularity among men. The trend, attributed to pop culture influences such as the "Mad Men" look, has led to the opening of several high-end barbershops in Singapore, offering premium services including hot towel shaves and straight-razor shaves. Experts say the traditional wet shave offers a closer shave and reduces the risk of razor burn and ingrown hairs. As the market for men's grooming continues to grow, luxury barbershops are capitalizing on the trend, offering a range of services and high-end products.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Sim Lian subsidiary won an $87.8 million HDB contract for a project in Sengkang. Hengxin Tech received in-principle approval to convert its listing from primary to secondary on the Singapore Exchange. Transcorp reported a $10.6 million net profit for H1, with an interim dividend of 15 cents per share. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case.

site_title: Oceanus still in a sea of red ink
summary: Oceanus Group, an abalone producer, reported a narrower quarterly loss of 19.1 million yuan, down from a year-ago deficit of 46.4 million yuan. The company revised its 2013 results to a significantly wider loss of 444.7 million yuan due to asset revaluation and losses. Its auditor withheld an opinion on the company's financial state, citing insufficient evidence. Oceanus is discussing funding solutions for its existing loans and warrants issue, which is due in 2015, and focusing on growing its abalone stock rather than selling them, amid weak abalone prices.

site_title: No surprise, his money's on Italy
summary: Italy's commercial director for Juventus, Francesco Calvo, is confident that his country will win the World Cup, despite being a 7th-favorite to lift the trophy. He believes Italy has what it takes to repeat its 2006 World Cup victory and become the first European team to win on South American soil. Calvo rates striker Mario Balotelli highly, citing his excellent performance at Euro 2012, and plans to bring in Ciro Immobile in the second half if needed. Juventus is also set to play an exhibition game in Singapore on August 16 against a Singapore Selection team.

site_title: Qingdao scandal: S'pore banks say they review their loans regularly
summary: Singapore's three local banks, OCBC, DBS, and UOB, have reviewed their loans amid a widening scandal involving false receipts at China's Qingdao port. OCBC has no loans to affected companies, while DBS is "not terribly concerned" as its counterparties are other banks. UOB regularly reviews all loans as part of its risk management process and does not have Qingdao-related trade or commodities exposure. The scandal has led to a drop in copper prices, with DBS and OCBC underperforming due to concerns surrounding their China-related exposure.

site_title: Car, watch, jewellery sales lose lustre
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 9% in April, driven by double-digit drops in car, watch, and jewellery sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales contracted 1.3%, with watches and jewellery experiencing a 16.3% fall. Economists attribute the decline to weakened tourist arrivals, particularly from China, which saw a 5.2% year-on-year contraction in March. The slump in discretionary spending is expected to continue, with some economists predicting a lift in retail spending in May, particularly from consumer electronics ahead of the FIFA World Cup.

site_title: Q1 unemployment up a tad at 2%
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate rose to 2% in the first quarter of 2014, up from 1.8% in December, but still remains in full employment. The increase is attributed to more Singaporeans, particularly the less educated, joining the labor market in search of employment due to higher wage jobs. Job openings outnumbered job seekers, but the seasonally adjusted ratio of job vacancies to jobless persons dipped. The number of layoffs eased, with 3,110 workers made redundant in the first quarter, compared to 2,120 in the previous year.

site_title: Quality seafood, supermarket prices
summary: Brothers Christopher and Karl Chong have launched GoFresh, an online seafood retailer that aims to bring restaurant-quality ingredients to the masses at supermarket prices. The site, which lists live seafood and frozen meats, was launched after the Chong brothers left their roles at Groupon Singapore and collaborated with Julian Lee and his sister Joanne Lui, who run Freshable, a seafood import and distribution business. GoFresh promises a risk-free experience, allowing customers to return items for a full refund, and plans to expand its offerings to include other fresh items in the future.

site_title: QT Vascular's Q1 hit by fair-value loss and higher expenses
summary: QT Vascular reported a net loss of $9.2 million for Q1 2014, compared to a $4.1 million loss the previous year, mainly due to a $2.4 million fair value loss. Revenue soared to $2.8 million, driven by increased sales of its "Chocolate PTA" balloon catheter. The company received FDA approval for its "Chocolate PTCA" catheter and remains optimistic about future growth, citing a positive demand outlook for medical devices.

site_title: Conflict in Iraq rattles markets
summary: Conflict in Iraq has sent shockwaves through financial markets, with oil prices jumping to a nine-month high due to supply concerns. The escalation of sectarian violence in the country has raised fears of disruptions to oil production, particularly from Iraq, the second-largest Opec producer. Despite this, Asian markets have remained upbeat, while the US market experienced a sell-off. The crisis has heightened global uncertainty, with investors closely monitoring the situation.

site_title: Sites for the seafoodie
summary: Three online seafood stores in Singapore have recently expanded their offerings: Rakuten, The Fishwives, and Greenwood Fish Bistro. Rakuten partners with local merchants to sell sashimi-grade seafood from Japan, while The Fishwives focuses on healthy, unadulterated food with no additives. Greenwood Fish Bistro offers exotic coldwater seafood imported from around the world. Prices vary across stores, ranging from $5 to $180, with options for frozen and fresh seafood, including sashimi-grade fish and live oysters.

site_title: Business friend
summary: Renault has revamped its Kangoo model, offering a business-friendly alternative with a twin version. The updated model features a new design language, with almond-shaped headlamps and a flowing black grille. The six-door model has two front doors, two sliding side doors, and two rear doors, with a spacious interior and cargo capacity of 4.6 cubic meters. The turbodiesel version, available in a long wheelbase, offers effortless performance and low noise levels, making it a cost-effective workhorse. The revised model is priced at $77,900, with a lower price point compared to the Mercedes-Benz Citan.

site_title: Spain's temples of art
summary: Spain boasts a rich cultural landscape, with several cities claiming to be art and architecture hubs. The country's artistic roots began with the works of Spanish masters such as El Greco, Velazquez, and Goya, who influenced Picasso's style. Today, cities like Madrid, Barcelona, and Seville showcase impressive museums, classical art, and architecture. The Prado Museum in Madrid is a must-visit, featuring works by Goya, Velazquez, and Bosch. The Reina Sofia Museum in Madrid is renowned for its 20th-century art collection, including Picasso's Guernica. Seville's Royal Alcazar palace complex is a stunning example of classical architecture, while Bilbao's Guggenheim Museum is a modern art destination.

site_title: MAS overnight yuan facility to back offshore renminbi market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced a new overnight yuan facility to support the growing offshore renminbi market, providing up to 5 billion yuan in overnight funds starting July 1. The facility complements the existing MAS RMB facility, allowing corporates and individuals in the Suzhou Industrial Park to conduct cross-border RMB transactions with Singapore. The move aims to bolster market confidence and facilitate the continued expansion of RMB activities in Singapore, with the Singapore RMB market expected to grow further.

site_title: Facing it naturally
summary: Spas are incorporating natural ingredients into their treatments to offer holistic healing experiences. Several spas, including Spa Club, Immanuel Beauty, and Green Spa by Santaverde (Xingu), are using organic materials and plants to boost the therapeutic benefits of their treatments. These spas offer a range of treatments, from crystal healing programs to fruit and herbal facials, and emphasize the importance of relaxation and rejuvenation. The use of natural ingredients is seen as a key differentiator in a highly competitive market, and spas are leveraging this trend to attract clients seeking a more holistic approach to wellness.

site_title: Living the wild life
summary: Safari guide Peter Allison has spent nearly two decades in the bush, where he has learned to stand his ground against wild animals. Allison advises against running from predators, instead suggesting that making oneself appear larger and showing confidence can be effective. He has had several close calls, including being chased by buffalos and lions, but has trained himself to react calmly. Allison's experiences have also led him to write books on his adventures, including "Whatever You Do, Don't Run" and "How to Walk A Puma." He now works with Wilderness Safaris, a leading eco-tourism operator, and aims to promote conservation and sustainable tourism in Africa.

site_title: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive
summary: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive, a charity event, is not mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: Iskandar 'complements, not competes with' Singapore industries
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's trade ministers emphasized that the Iskandar development region in Johor will complement, not compete with, Singapore's manufacturing sector. The 60:40 project between Ascendas and UEM Sunrise's Nusajaya Tech Park aims to attract international firms and Singapore companies looking to expand. The 210-hectare tech park, developed in phases over nine years, will offer industrial and office space for precision engineering, electronics, and logistics companies. With prices averaging RM380 (S$148) per square foot, it is seen as an attractive alternative to Singapore's industrial land.

site_title: Cooper cool
summary: The new Mini Cooper has been unveiled, boasting a 1.5-liter, three-cylinder turbocharged engine that produces 136 hp and 220 Nm, a 42% increase in torque. The engine is paired with a six-speed automatic gearbox and offers improved performance, particularly in the mid-range. The car's handling remains confident, but its refinement has compromised its razor-sharp handling. The updated interior features improved ride comfort, cabin noise reduction, and enhanced quality with leather seats and a new fascia. The Cooper is priced at $145,300.

site_title: Brazil hopes for smooth opener as tournament finally kicks off
summary: Brazil's highly anticipated World Cup opener against Croatia has begun, despite concerns about the country's preparations and discontent among locals. The tournament, which has been plagued by construction delays and budget overruns, has been overshadowed by issues at home. Hundreds of thousands of foreign fans have arrived, but enthusiasm among Brazilians has been muted. The opening match, played at a newly built stadium in Sao Paulo, marks the start of the month-long tournament.

site_title: The tuft guys
summary: A hyper-masculine barbershop, Truefitt & Hill, offers a stylish and comfortable experience for grooming. The article also highlights various lifestyle and business stories, including a new restaurant, a zero-waste initiative, and a financial literacy program. Additionally, it covers corporate news, such as the retirement of OCBC CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor, as well as a mandatory offer for PSC shares.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC shares dive as takeover talks end
summary: STATS ChipPAC shares dropped 10% to 58.5 cents after talks with a third party interested in taking over the loss-making semiconductor group were discontinued. The company said discussions with other interested parties were still ongoing. The stock initially fell 14.6% to an intra-day low of 55.5 cents.

site_title: Youyue acquires China green tech firm
summary: Youyue International has acquired Chinese firm Harbin Promlite Energy Saving Technology Co Ltd through the full acquisition of Singapore-incorporated WYW Capital Pte Ltd. The acquisition is part of Youyue's bid to branch out into sustainable development business. The deal was facilitated by Youyue's controlling shareholder Zhao Lizhi and executive director Wang Yousheng. The acquisition is expected to expand Youyue's presence in the green tech market.

site_title: Samsung launches featherweight tablet
summary: Samsung has unveiled its thinnest and lightest tablet yet, the Galaxy Tab S, which measures 6.6mm thick and weighs 294g for the 8.4-inch model. The tablet is nearly 1mm thinner than the iPad Air and comes in two sizes with prices starting at US$399 for the 16GB Wi-Fi model, comparable to the iPad Air. Samsung aims to challenge Apple's market share, which fell from 40.2% to 32.5% in the first quarter of this year, and is expected to see double-digit growth in tablet sales.

site_title: China group to build creative hub in Sydney
summary: China's Greenland group plans to build a $440 million, 67-story residential tower in Sydney, featuring a $25 million creative hub with facilities for dance, theatre, music, film, and visual arts. The project, valued at $25 million, will be the tallest residential building in Australia and provide a space for a creative fellowship program. The city of Sydney has signed a 99-year lease for the hub, which is expected to open in late 2017, bringing significant economic, cultural, and community benefits to the city.

site_title: Transgenders' blight
summary: Avant Theatre's artistic director G Selvanathan has staged a sequel to his 1991 play "Akka," titled "Akka: The End," to highlight the struggles of Singapore's transgender community. The play, set to premiere in July, will be performed entirely in Tamil with English subtitles, focusing on the challenges faced by transgenders in finding employment and facing harassment. Selvanathan aims to raise awareness and spark thought-provoking discussions, stating that theatre is meant to evoke emotions and inspire change.

site_title: Feminist classic A Doll's House gets a reboot
summary: A Doll's House, a 1879 feminist play by Henrik Ibsen, is being reimagined with a new production. The classic play, which follows a woman's decision to leave her family, has been widely staged globally, with UNESCO recognizing Nora as a symbol of women fighting for liberation and equality. The play's themes of independence and self-discovery continue to resonate with audiences today, cementing its status as a pioneering feminist work.

site_title: Suffering for art
summary: Scarlett Johansson stars as an alien who takes the form of a mysterious woman in Glasgow, seeking out young men for nefarious purposes. The film, directed by Jonathan Glazer, is a moody contemplation of identity and alienation, with minimal dialogue and sparse use of light. Johansson's performance is praised for its bravery, and the film's experimental style can be both unsettling and effective. Despite its challenges, the film tells a unique story of an alien's struggles with human interaction, with Johansson willing to "suffer for her art."

site_title: Wilson Sons to pay 50% dividend
summary: Wilson Sons, a Brazilian ports and tugboat operator, plans to pay a 50% dividend to shareholders after investing over $1 billion to expand operations. The company, backed by Aberdeen Asset Management, expects to sustain this dividend ratio as it expands along Brazil's coastline. Founded in 1837, Wilson Sons has reported record earnings and its shares have reached their highest level since listing in 2007. The company's investments are expected to deliver profit growth, with a robust potential for dividend increases, according to its chief financial officer.

site_title: Ascott inks franchise pacts in Vientiane, Bali
summary: Ascott Limited has signed franchise agreements for two serviced residences in Vientiane, Laos, and Bali, Indonesia. The 116-unit Somerset Vientiane will open in the fourth quarter, while the 194-unit Citadines Kuta Beach Bali is scheduled for August. The agreements mark a new milestone for Ascott, allowing the company to expand its scale and presence in the region. This move is driven by the growing demand for international-class serviced residences in Laos, where economic reforms are attracting foreign investment and expatriates.

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q1 net dips 4%; revenue up 36%
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singapore-based construction group, reported a net profit of $14.6 million for Q1 FY2015, down 4% from the previous year. Revenue increased by 36% to $24.2 million, driven by a $114.3 million contract for a hotel block. The group remains cautiously optimistic, investing in projects with consistent revenue and profitability streams, and expects the cooling measures to moderate prices.

site_title: UK minister urges BOE to clamp down on risky mortgages
summary: UK business minister Vince Cable urged the Bank of England to clamp down on mortgages with high loan-to-income ratios, citing concerns over booming house prices. Cable, who described some lenders as "appalled" for lending up to 5 times income, referenced past housing booms where 3-3.5 times income was seen as stable. His comments come ahead of key annual addresses by finance minister George Osborne and BOE governor Mark Carney.

site_title: Healthcare policies boost Prudential's premiums
summary: Prudential Singapore saw a 18% increase in new business premiums to $706 million in 2013, driven by strong sales in healthcare policies such as PruShield. The insurer's flagship health product has around 400,000 policyholders, and Prudential has found that many people are bewildered by healthcare advice and options. To address this, the company launched a helpline called "PRUhealthcare Assist" to provide guidance on cover, doctors, and hospitals. Prudential also sees growth in the high net worth business, with new premiums rising 63% in 2013.

site_title: Hunt on for pirates after tanker hijacking
summary: Malaysia is hunting for pirates who hijacked a tanker off its eastern coast, stealing approximately one million liters of diesel fuel. The pirates, armed with machetes, took control of the tanker for about 10 hours, siphoning off fuel and destroying communication equipment before escaping. This incident marks the latest in a spate of piracy attacks in Malaysia's waters, which have also affected Indonesia and Singapore. The Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency has activated 24-hour sea patrols to prevent similar attacks, and the International Maritime Bureau has urged maritime agencies to bolster security measures.

site_title: Unlocking time in a bottle
summary: A wine is ready to drink when the drinker is ready, not necessarily when it reaches full maturity. Conventional wisdom suggests a wine should be fully mature before consumption, but this is not always the case. Drinking a wine at a young age can be beneficial for learning about its maturation process and personal enjoyment. The article highlights three examples of wines that are not yet ready to drink, including a 15-year-old Richebourg and a 9-year-old Chambolle Musigny, emphasizing the importance of patience and proper timing for wine appreciation.

site_title: Return of retro with Lee's Hotpants
summary: Dick Lee's musical "Hotpants" is set to return to Singapore, a decade after its initial production in 1997. The show, a retro tale of three schoolgirls forming a singing group to win a Talentime competition, features a new cast including Nikki Muller and Denise Tan. The musical is a nostalgic homage to the 1970s, with Lee expressing his obsession with the era and its iconic fashion, such as hotpants. The show will run from August 14 to 30 at the Drama Centre Theatre, with tickets available from S$40 to S$83.

site_title: Malaysian housing developers ignoring freebie guidelines
summary: Malaysian housing developers are ignoring guidelines on freebies, offering rebates instead of reducing prices, seven months after cooling measures were introduced. A survey by the House Buyers Association found that 20 large and 10 smaller developers were caught flouting guidelines, and many banks are still basing financing on SPA price rather than net selling price. This has led to buyers paying higher prices, making affordable housing a distant dream. The HBA urges banks to stop easy financing schemes and for the government to enforce greater transparency and empower house buyers with information.

site_title: Limp-wristed stab at frontier humour
summary: Seth MacFarlane's comedy film "A Million Ways to Die in the West" fails to deliver, relying on crude humor and outdated jokes. Despite having a star-studded cast, including Charlize Theron and Liam Neeson, the film lacks freshness and comic impact. A weak spoof of western comedies, it fails to live up to MacFarlane's previous success with "Ted." The film's disjointed tone and lack of humor result in a disappointing and uninspired effort from the director and writer.

site_title: By special invitation - from the Queen
summary: Queen Elizabeth II hosted an exclusive garden party at Buckingham Palace, attended by 8,000 guests, including charity workers, civic dignitaries, and veterans. The event, which drew ordinary citizens from around the country, featured a 17ha garden with 320 types of wildflowers and offered free refreshments. The Queen, accompanied by Prince Philip, Kate Middleton, and other royal family members, walked through the garden, where guests formed lanes for the royals to pass through. The event, which took place on June 10, was seen as a celebration of community contributions and good manners, with a strict ban on photography and cameras.

site_title: AirAsia debuts in India amid price war
summary: AirAsia has launched its India venture, aiming to break even in four months amidst intense competition from local rivals offering ultra-low base fares. The airline industry in India faces significant challenges, including estimated annual losses of $22 per passenger and a projected $10 billion loss over the next decade. With the entry of AirAsia, the competition heightens, and the challenge for the airline to make a profit while reducing costs remains.

site_title: Home of millionaire accused of murder sets Aussie sale record
summary: A Sydney harbourfront mansion once owned by millionaire Ron Medich, accused of murder, has been sold for A$40 million, setting a 2014 Australian record. The five-bedroom home, with harbour views and a private jetty, was sold to a local buyer on Tuesday night through LJ Hooker Corp Double Bay. This sale follows another transaction in the same suburb for over A$30 million last week.

site_title: Cutting a swathe for Asian women on Broadway
summary: Korean-born American actress and playwright Asa Gim Palomera is set to stage her play "Women of Asia" in Singapore, marking a milestone for Asian women on Broadway. Written 26 years ago, the play explores the challenges faced by Asian women in different situations, perpetuated by tradition and prejudice. The six-segment play, featuring a diverse cast, aims to examine attitudes towards misery, loneliness, and exploitation, and to spark humanist discussions. The production, produced by GenerAsia, will run from June 19-28 at LaSalle Flexible Performance Space.

site_title: Asian conglomerates do better than those in the West: study
summary: A new study by Bain & Company found that Asian conglomerates outperform their Western counterparts, defying conventional wisdom. The study analyzed 49 large conglomerates in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Vietnam over 10 years, concluding that superior performance was not guaranteed across South-east Asian economies. Successful conglomerates require privileged access, government ties, scale, and a willingness to adapt to volatile economies. Key findings include the importance of focused portfolios, regional leadership, and international exposure as economies mature.

site_title: Changi unveils fund to cut airlines' costs
summary: Changi Airport has launched a $100 million fund to support airlines, aiming to reduce costs and boost productivity. The Growth and Assistance Incentive (Gain) programme will provide airlines with lower operating costs, including 50% off aircraft parking fees and 15% off aerobridge fees. The fund will also encourage airlines to increase transit traffic at Changi and invest in marketing campaigns to attract more tourists. The initiative aims to strengthen Changi's hub status and position Singapore as a major air gateway to and from the region.

site_title: MediShield Life a welcome addition
summary: MediShield Life, a new healthcare financing scheme in Singapore, aims to provide higher payouts and lower out-of-pocket expenses for CPF members. The scheme offers life-long coverage, including ward costs, surgical procedures, and outpatient cancer therapy, and covers pre-existing illnesses. Premiums are expected to be affordable, potentially funded by Medisave contributions. The scheme is seen as a welcome addition to address rising healthcare costs, but individuals must consider their existing healthcare coverage and potential mismatches with private Integrated Shield plans.

site_title: Tougher terms ahead for frequent fliers
summary: United Airlines has announced that starting March 1, 2015, frequent-flier miles will be earned based on ticket prices, not distance flown, favoring those who pay full fare. Members earning elite status will receive more points per dollar spent. The change aligns with Delta Air Lines' similar shift, leaving American Airlines as the only major US carrier still using the traditional miles-based system. Experts warn that this change could lead to more stringent redemption requirements in the future.

site_title: Regulatory needs impact returns of banks' China units: Barclays
summary: The China subsidiaries of Hong Kong and Singapore banks face low returns due to strict regulatory restrictions and heavy investment spending, averaging 5.5% in 2013. This is lower than the 20%+ ROE of large local Chinese banks. Foreign banks are also facing margin pressure from gradual interest-rate liberalisation, slower volume growth, and potential rise in credit costs. Despite poor returns, banks remain committed to the Chinese market, citing opportunities in RMB internationalisation, deregulation, and government initiatives.

site_title: Sealed with a Hui kiss
summary: Sam Hui, the "King of Cantopop," performed a 37-song set at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, wowing a crowd of 5,000 mostly middle-aged and senior citizens. The 65-year-old singer, known for his generosity, gave lucky front-row fans a kiss, a gesture that has landed him in controversy in the past. Despite some stiffness in his dancing, Hui's show was a hit, with his sons Scott and Ryan joining him on stage for note-perfect covers of his hits. The concert was a testament to Hui's ability to work a crowd and deliver an unforgettable experience.

site_title: Acquisition expenses dampen Del Monte's earnings
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of $42.8 million for the transitional four months ended April 30, compared to a profit of $6.6 million in the same period pre-consolidation. The loss was attributed to non-recurring items such as acquisition-related fees and higher costs. Revenue increased to $379 million, up from $128 million pre-consolidation. Managing director Joselito D Campos Jr stated that the bottom line will be weighed down by higher costs for the next year, but earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) are expected to strengthen in the 2015 fiscal year.

site_title: Blatter ready to seek fifth term as Fifa president
summary: Sepp Blatter, the 78-year-old FIFA president, announced his readiness to seek a fifth term despite calls for him to step down amidst controversy. The FIFA congress voted not to consider age and term limits for officials, allowing Blatter to potentially run for life. He denied having designs on a lifetime presidency, saying he is "ready to accompany you in the future." A strong chance of victory at the next May FIFA congress is expected.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Singaporeans can experience the country's lesser-known past through the National Heritage Board's "Balik Pulau" exhibition, which explores the islands that made up the archipelago. The exhibition features video interviews, archival pictures, and artefacts until August 10. Meanwhile, Le Noir returns with new acts, including The Wheel of Death, at the MasterCard Theatre until June 29. American artist Gary Simmons' solo exhibition "Extant Phantoms" showcases his early works at Ikkan Art until June 28, while up-and-coming Korean artist Jieun Park's "A Little Talk" exhibition runs at REDSEA Gallery until June 29.

site_title: Eyeing gold at the box-office
summary: Singaporean director Jack Neo, known for his drama-comedies, acknowledges criticism from critics but attributes his box-office success to his ability to push the envelope with his films, which often tackle local issues. Despite negative reviews, Neo's movies have consistently broken box-office records and are well-received across the region. He sees himself as a guinea pig for the industry, prioritizing artistic expression over commercial appeal. Neo credits his ability to balance artistic and commercial success as key to his enduring popularity as Singapore's undisputed local box-office champ.

site_title: Father's Day guide to buying art
summary: A Father's Day guide to buying art for the man of the house is offered, catering to various tastes and interests. Options include abstract artworks by Filip Gudovic ($2,800-$3,200), psychedelic street graffiti-inspired pieces by Wedhar Riyadi ($3,400), Optical Art or Op Art posters ($20-$1,570), reproductions of Old Masters' works ($20), nostalgic photos by Philipp Aldrup ($370), traditional Chinese ink paintings by Tay Bak Chiang ($6,800), and photos of demolished HDB blocks by Darren Soh ($600). Additionally, photography works by Sebastiao Salgado ($11,000-$96,000) are also available.

site_title: The Game Plan
summary: Companies are taking a lighthearted approach to the World Cup, with many embracing the tournament as an opportunity to bond with employees. CEOs and health experts offer tips for surviving the month-long event, including adopting an investment strategy, planning ahead, eating healthy, staying calm, relaxing in style, and getting driven. Some companies are even organizing World Cup-themed events and activities to keep employees engaged and motivated. Despite the potential disruption to productivity, many bosses are willing to turn a blind eye to staff's enthusiasm for the tournament.

site_title: Giving it all for 3D Naked Ambition
summary: Hong Kong comedian Chapman To lost 20 pounds for the 3D Naked Ambition film, adhering to a strict diet and exercise routine inspired by Sylvester Stallone's Rocky character. To worked with seven Japanese adult video actresses, whom he credits with boosting his confidence. The film, a reboot of a 2003 adult comedy, features topless scenes and showcases To's dedication to physical transformation. To's experience highlights the challenges and benefits of taking on a demanding role for a film.

site_title: URA's landscape renewal to cover more areas
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced enhancements to the Landscaping for Urban Spaces and High Rises (LUSH) programme, expanding its coverage to more areas in Singapore. The policy, dubbed LUSH 2.0, now requires developers to replace at least 40% of the site area with green communal spaces in strategic areas, and 30-40% in other areas. The policy aims to increase greenery island-wide, with the goal of maintaining Singapore's identity as a "city in the garden".

site_title: The world, their stage
summary: A new program by Act 3 Theatre Company aims to teach drama skills to teenagers to improve their performance in the service industry. The 10-session acting course, led by drama teacher Amelia George, focuses on empowerment and building confidence. The program's creators, Colin Goh and Ruby Lim-Yang, believe that drama skills can be applied to real-life situations, particularly in the service industry. The first eight participants will receive training and then work at a Japanese pancake shop, where they will hone their communication skills. The goal is to equip teenagers with the confidence to succeed in the workforce.

site_title: Blatter told not to seek fifth term as Fifa president
summary: Sepp Blatter, FIFA president, has been advised by European soccer leaders not to run for a fifth term due to the governing body's damaged reputation. Blatter, 78, had initially stepped down but reversed the decision, sparking concerns over corruption allegations linked to the 2022 World Cup awarding to Qatar. Critics, including Dutch Football Association chairman Michael van Praag, have linked bribery and corruption to Blatter's presidency, citing a "bad reputation" for the organization.

site_title: Tokyo's Olympic venue plans under review
summary: Tokyo's venue plans for the 2020 Summer Olympic Games are under review due to rising construction and labor costs. The review, prompted by a sharp increase in Japanese consumption tax and rebuilding efforts, may lead to a scaling back of facilities. The original proposal, which budgeted 153.8 billion yen for venues, did not account for the impact of the tax hike and rising construction costs. A revised plan will be submitted to the International Olympic Committee in February 2025, with the possibility of reducing the scope of venues or costs.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: LifeBrandz, a nightclub operator, posted a wider net loss of $872,000 in Q3 due to weaker crowds and increased competition, reducing revenue by 10% to $5 million. In contrast, TTJ Holdings' Q3 profit more than doubled to $6.2 million. Mirach Energy signed a non-binding term sheet for potential drilling work in its Indonesian concessions. Meanwhile, OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor.

site_title: For the love of the beautiful game
summary: There is no article content provided for the news summarization.

site_title: Those squads now in Brazil? They're worth a total S$6.6 billion
summary: The top 10 teams at the 2014 World Cup are valued at a combined £3.13 billion, with Brazil's squad worth £407 million, led by striker Neymar and defender David Luiz. Spain comes in second with £315.2 million, and Belgium's squad is valued at £222.7 million. England's team is worth £179.6 million, behind Portugal, Argentina, and France but ahead of Germany. Meanwhile, Iran's team is valued at £3.6 million, making it the "cheapest" squad at the tournament.

site_title: Nature's role in Asian culture
summary: Artist Lucy Davis's exhibition explores the connection between culture and nature in South-east Asia through a collaborative art installation featuring wood. The project began in 2009 with Davis collecting discarded wooden objects in Little India and has since evolved into a multifaceted exploration of wood's journey from production to disposal. The exhibition, part of Davis's "Migrant Ecologies" project, aims to raise awareness about deforestation and its impact on the environment. Through intimate details and bigger picture representations, the exhibition showcases the complex relationship between culture, nature, and the human experience.

site_title: Emirates cancels order for 70 A350 aircraft
summary: Emirates has cancelled its order for 70 A350 aircraft, a significant loss for Airbus, with estimated losses totaling around a tenth of the company's 2014 orders. The cancellation, made following a review of Emirates' fleet requirements, affects a deal worth $16.5 billion. Airbus remains confident in the A350, with 28 airlines ordering 742 aircraft six months ahead of the plane's entry into service. The decision sent Airbus shares down over 5% and Rolls-Royce warned of a £2.6 billion loss.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Changi Airport launches a $100 million fund to help airlines cope with costs. Asian conglomerates outperform Western counterparts in the business landscape. The Iskandar development region in Malaysia complements Singapore's manufacturing sector. A $6.6 billion fortune can buy the entire Brazilian World Cup football squad. SingTel's acquisition of Amobee received muted market reaction. Youyue International acquires a Chinese green tech firm. A new technology prevents fogging up of surfaces. Indonesia's presidential election affects foreign investment. India's economy faces challenges due to lending slowdown and monsoon forecasts.

site_title: Downside of populist campaigns in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's presidential campaign is characterized by populist rhetoric from candidates Joko Widodo and Prabowo Subianto, prioritizing nationalism and protectionism over business-friendliness. Both candidates propose limiting foreign investment, imposing export taxes, and increasing infrastructure spending, with no clear plan for funding. This could lead to a nationalistic atmosphere that affects investment in other sectors, potentially harming Indonesia's economy, which is already slowing. The country needs foreign investment to cover its current account gap and needs to reassure financial markets of its fiscal problems.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Sabana Reit maintained its investment grade rating by Standard & Poor's with a stable outlook. CCM Group plans to change its name to Singapore eDevelopment Ltd, reflecting its new business activities. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half, prompting CGSI to downgrade the stock to 'hold'.

site_title: MSCI excludes China A shares from global indices
summary: MSCI has decided not to include China's mainland-based A shares in its global emerging markets index, citing trading restrictions, including a quota system and controls on same-day trading. This decision aims to encourage China to reduce restrictions to attract international investors. MSCI will instead introduce a standalone China A International Index, keeping shares under review for potential inclusion in the future. The decision is a setback for China's efforts to boost its stock market and promote the yuan's use in international trade.

site_title: Obama signs water projects bill to fund port deepening
summary: US President Barack Obama signed a $12.3 billion water-projects bill, authorizing 34 projects, including deepening ports to accommodate bigger ships. The law allows ports to pay upfront costs for deepening harbors and seek federal reimbursement. The dredging will enable US ports to handle super freighters, taking advantage of the Panama Canal's $5.2 billion expansion, scheduled for completion in 2015.

site_title: Fast CME Group access now being offered via Marketprizm
summary: CME Group has partnered with Marketprizm to provide fast access to its raw market data and order routing services at Singapore Exchange (SGX), catering to high-frequency traders. This move expands alternatives for traders seeking low-latency access in Singapore.

site_title: At fever pitch worldwide
summary: The 2014 World Cup is set to kick off in Brazil, with the first match taking place on Friday, sparking concerns about productivity and work-life balance as fans and players prepare for the tournament. A survey found nearly 40% of football fans plan to stay up late to watch matches and may call in sick or take leave the next day. The tournament is expected to boost Brazil's economy and infrastructure, but protests and construction delays have marred the build-up. The host country faces immense pressure to win the tournament, with many top teams vying for the championship.

site_title: Inflation forecasts cut but cost worries stay: MAS poll
summary: Singapore's inflation forecasts have been cut to 2.2% for 2014, down from 2.8% in the previous survey, but economists expect domestic costs to remain high due to persistent wage pressures. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) core inflation is forecast to remain elevated at 2.4% this year. Economists expect the Singapore economy to grow 3.8% in 2014, with manufacturing and wholesale trade forecast to expand, but accommodation and food services growth is expected to moderate.

site_title: Shelved Las Vegas projects are being revived
summary: Investor confidence in the US real estate market is evident in the revival of shelved Las Vegas projects. Downtown Summerlin, a 43 ha office, entertainment, and retail complex, is being rebuilt after being halted by the recession. This development signals a recovery in the Las Vegas commercial real estate market, which has been littered with vacant buildings and abandoned construction sites. Other signs of investor confidence include Blackstone's deal to buy the Cosmopolitan resort and Genting's proposed resurrection of an abandoned project on Las Vegas Boulevard.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: SingTel's digital advertising arm Amobee acquired ad tech firms Adconion and Kontera for over US$350 million, solidifying its position as a global one-stop digital advertising platform. This move follows Amobee's acquisition of Adconion two years ago for US$321 million. The deal aims to enhance Amobee's capabilities and expand its offerings in the digital advertising market.

site_title: Denmark's Thorco Shipping eyes more ships, IPO
summary: Denmark's Thorco Shipping plans to expand its fleet by 50% in the coming years, aiming to list on the Copenhagen stock exchange when industry conditions improve. The company, controlled by the Stadil family, currently has 105 vessels and is looking to acquire vessels from banks that want to offload them due to financial difficulties. Analysts expect demand for multi-purpose shipping to pick up in the next few years, but industry players believe consolidation is needed to create a better balance between demand and supply.

site_title: Muted response to deals by SingTel's Amobee
summary: SingTel's acquisition of digital advertising companies Adconion and Kontera through its arm Amobee received a muted market reaction, with SingTel shares trading flat at $3.86. Analysts took a wait-and-see approach, citing early days for the acquisition's impact on profitability. Credit rating firms Moody's and Standard & Poor stated that the acquisitions will not affect SingTel's ratings, citing a high-quality company with low credit risk. The acquisitions are expected to require additional cash investment, but SingTel's liquidity profile and flexibility to provide financial support to the newly-acquired entities are seen as mitigating factors.

site_title: Singapore to benefit from tighter Asean integration: report
summary: Singapore is expected to benefit from tighter Asean integration, with increased intra-regional trade and foreign direct investment (FDI) in services. The country's GDP gain is likely to stem from services liberalisation, given its status as a net services exporter. However, Singapore needs to address the pressures of cost normalisation, which could impact its export competitiveness. Despite this, Citi Research remains bullish on Asean's prospects for sustained economic growth, citing favourable demographics and rising consumption.

site_title: Airbus pitches A380 after Emirates snub
summary: Airbus is pitching its A380 flagship to US airlines after Emirates canceled a massive order, its largest ever. The planemaker showcased the jet in a promotional flight over New York, aiming to win over US carriers that have so far shunned the plane. A Russian-born financier, Mark Lapidus, is also leasing 20 A380s to airlines, but has yet to secure any customers. Airbus hopes to revive sales for the world's largest commercial jet, which has been struggling to find buyers.

site_title: World Cup's underwater oracles
summary: A Singaporean fish farm, Qian Hu Fish Farm, has trained an arowana fish to predict the outcome of the World Cup. Big Huat, a $2,000 albino silver arowana, was given three containers labeled "Brazil", "Draw", and "Croatia" and was observed to swim to the "Draw" container, indicating a potential stalemate in the match between Brazil and Croatia. This unusual prediction method is being offered to football fans during the game period.

site_title: Vertical garden at CDL condo is world's largest
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has set a world record for the largest vertical garden, measuring 2,289 square meters, at its condominium project in Singapore. The garden, known as Tree House, reduces energy consumption by 15-30% and yields energy savings of over 2.4 million kilowatt-hours per year. CDL invests 2-5% of construction costs in eco-friendly features, and its projects have previously set records for solar panels and zero-energy buildings.

site_title: Correction
summary: Khazanah Nasional's select group of large government-linked corporations (GLCs) has not tripled in market capitalization to RM425 billion. The actual figure is the G20's market cap, which has tripled in 10 years. The GLCs controlled by Khazanah, including Tenaga Nasional, TM, Axiata, and CIMB, have seen their market capitalization increase. The error was reported in an article on June 11, 2014.

site_title: Hilton to open 5 more hotels in Myanmar
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings plans to open five more hotels in Myanmar over the next three years, despite delays in its maiden project. The company has signed management agreements with Eden Group Company Ltd for the hotels, with two existing properties set to rebrand as Hilton hotels in October 2014 and the other three opening in 2016 and 2017. This expansion comes as the country experiences a hotel boom, driven by a surge in tourists, with only six five-star hotels operating at the end of 2013.

site_title: Total Access to delist from SGX
summary: Thailand's second-largest mobile operator, Total Access Communication, plans to delist its secondary listing on the Singapore Exchange mainboard due to low trading volume, compliance costs, and a desire to raise funds only through its Thailand primary listing. The indicative last day of trading is Sept 16, and the delisting date is Sept 29. Shareholders can continue to trade shares on the Stock Exchange of Thailand, with a deadline of Sept 22 for transferring shares to the Thailand Securities Depository Co.

site_title: Famous Irish hotel, two others go on sale for 30m euros
summary: Famous Irish hotel, The Malton, along with the Metropolis Hotel in Cork and the Kilkenny Remand Hotel, are being sold for 30 million euros. The 172-bedroom Malton, opened in 1854, was a favorite among Jacqueline Kennedy and other notable guests. The sale comes after domestic and overseas investors expressed interest, following a real estate bubble burst in 2008. The decision is seen as a boost to the Irish economy, with improving demand for business properties. The hotels are profitable and expected to attract considerable interest.

site_title: Vietnamese developer to tap nascent suburban-style homes
summary: Vietnamese developer Nam Long Investment Corp plans to build suburban-style communities, targeting a 10-fold increase in market capitalization to US$1 billion by 2020. The company aims to capitalize on rising demand for affordable housing in South-east Asia as incomes surge. This follows a challenging national property market, where strong demand has helped overcome obstacles, according to the International Finance Corp. Nam Long will develop suburban-style communities in provinces like Long An, a gateway to Vietnam's Mekong Delta.

site_title: IMF launches index to avert property bubbles
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has launched a new index, the Global House Price Watch, to monitor property prices and prevent asset bubbles and financial crises. The index, which covers 51 countries, including Asia-Pacific nations prone to property price boom and bust cycles, will provide a one-stop shop for data on housing indicators. The IMF aims to prompt policy actions to moderate housing cycles, as 33 countries have shown increases in house prices relative to rents and incomes over the past year, with some nations experiencing significant price declines.

site_title: First Resources in favour despite drop in crude palm oil prices
summary: Singapore-listed Indonesian palm oil firm First Resources remains favoured by two research houses despite a 17% drop in crude palm oil prices. Citi Research cited the company's low valuation and faster growth as reasons for its favourable stance. First Resources last traded at $2.35 a share, making it one of the cheaper and faster-growing firms in the sector.

site_title: Impact of shale gas revolution on S'pore 'minimal'
summary: Singapore's chemical industry is unlikely to be significantly impacted by the shale gas revolution in the US, according to Richard Bolte, chairman and CEO of BDP International. The US shale gas industry's energy costs have lowered, but Singapore's logistics hub and specialty chemicals sector are well-positioned to remain unaffected. In the near term, there may be some dislocation, but Singapore's growth and regional positioning will help it adapt to changes in the industry. Bolte also predicts a shift in trade flows from East-West to North-South within the region, with Asia becoming a key driver of growth for BDP International.

site_title: Ads following S'poreans into the Web
summary: Singapore's internet advertising market is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 10.3% to reach US$264 million by 2018, driven by the country's high broadband penetration and affluent population. The market is expected to outpace traditional newspaper advertising revenue, which will grow at a CAGR of 2.8%. Display ads will remain the largest segment, while search ads are expected to grow faster. The growth is attributed to Singapore's digitally advanced status and the increasing popularity of online gaming, with mobile games revenue forecast to reach US$223 million by 2018.

site_title: Push to speed up development as new sites released
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released new land sites in Singapore, including a 3.98-hectare commercial site in Paya Lebar and a 2.31-hectare residential site in Holland Village. The government has adopted a cautious approach to private housing, with sites on the reserve list launched only upon successful application by a developer. The enlarged Paya Lebar site can generate 167,160 square meters of gross floor area, while the Holland Village site can yield 580 private residences and 13,500 square meters of commercial space.

site_title: Commodity shipping demand to surge
summary: Commodity shipping demand is expected to surge 12% this year, outpacing the 4.7% expansion in the fleet of vessels that can transport iron ore, coal, and other dry-bulk goods. This is driven by falling iron ore prices, leading to increased shipments to China from countries like Brazil and Australia. Fleet utilisation is projected to jump 7.3% this year and 8.1% next year, marking the most significant increase in over five years.

site_title: Costs still high for wealth managers
summary: Wealth managers' cost-to-income ratio improved in 2013, but Boston Consulting Group warns that the improvement may not be sustainable due to high costs. Global wealth rose 14.6% to $152 trillion, with Asia-Pacific and ex-Japan experiencing the strongest growth. Revenues rose 8% for wealth managers, driven by fee increases and a shift towards fee-based pricing. However, average return on assets dropped, and costs, particularly legal and compliance costs, increased by 3.5%. Wealth managers need to strengthen their asset gathering capabilities and leverage digital technology to remain competitive.

site_title: Lufthansa shares nosedive amid Gulf challenge
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa AG saw its shares plummet as the airline cut its 2014-15 earnings forecasts due to a capacity surge at Gulf rivals, including Emirates, which is stripping traffic from traditional European bases. The airline now expects an operating profit of about 1 billion euros in 2014 and 2 billion euros in 2015, down from prior forecasts. A pilot strike and currency fluctuations are also weighing on earnings. The airline's CEO, Carsten Spohr, is facing the challenge posed by Gulf airlines, which are putting pressure on ticket prices.

site_title: Tiong Seng to make precast tunnel parts
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings, a Singapore-based construction group, has signed a joint venture agreement with two Japanese companies, Geostr Corp and Marubeni-Itochu Steel Pte Ltd, to manufacture and supply precast tunnel segments for the Singapore and Malaysia markets. The deal aims to capitalize on the growing pipeline of mass rapid transit projects and infrastructure construction in Singapore, in line with the Transport Ministry's plans to expand the rail network. This partnership is expected to enable Tiong Seng to target the Singapore market and tap into the Japanese companies' expertise.

site_title: New sites among the choicest in H2 slate
summary: Private housing sites at Lorong Puntong and Tampines Road in Singapore are among the choicest in the second half of 2014 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, according to property consultants. The Lorong Puntong site, near the upcoming Bright Hill MRT Station, is estimated to generate about 280 homes and could fetch a top bid of $650-$700 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The Kovan site, slated for launch in September, is estimated to yield about 340 homes and could fetch a top bid of $650-$700 psf ppr.

site_title: Jokowi, Prabowo taking protectionist stance
summary: Indonesian presidential candidates Jokowi and Prabowo have taken a protectionist stance, vowing to retain the country's ban on raw mineral ore exports, discourage foreign capital, and prioritize food self-sufficiency. Despite economic growth slowing and a budget deficit crisis, the candidates have focused on character rather than policy, with both releasing manifestos that mirror each other. The winner may adopt a more pragmatic view, but experts warn that backing away from populism may be difficult, and a change in policy is unlikely before the July 9 election.

site_title: S'pore firm charged over Pyongyang arms funding
summary: A Singapore-registered shipping firm, Chinpo Shipping Company, has been charged under the United Nations Act for allegedly financing North Korea's activities related to weapons of mass destruction. The firm is accused of transferring $72,000 to a shipping agent in Panama, which may have contributed to North Korea's nuclear programs. The company faces a maximum fine of $1 million and its accounts executive, Tan Hui Tin, could be jailed up to a month. The charges mark the first time Singapore has invoked the UN Act against a local company.

site_title: SIA to use A380 to serve Beijing from August
summary: Singapore Airlines will start using its Airbus A380 jumbo jet to serve Beijing from August, replacing two smaller aircraft flights. The A380 will operate three daily flights to Beijing, with the first flight departing from Changi Airport at 8:30 am and the return flight departing Beijing at 4:35 pm. This is part of SIA's expansion in China, which also includes flights to 11 other cities, operated by both A380 and Boeing 777 aircraft.

site_title: More US airports offer free Wi-Fi service
summary: Twelve of the US's 30 busiest airports now offer free Wi-Fi, up from nine in 2007, with a dozen others opting for a tiered plan. This shift aims to provide a pleasant experience for travelers, which can lead to economic development and business growth. The switch comes at a cost, with airports losing $1.5 million annually in revenue from the pay service. Users will no longer be exposed to online advertising, but may face slower speeds due to increased bandwidth consumption.

site_title: Emaar Malls 'raising US$750m through sukuk'
summary: Emaar Malls Group is raising US$750 million through a debut Islamic bond issue, with over US$5 billion in orders placed for the 10-year sukuk. The notes may price at 185 basis points above mid-swaps, according to sources. The move is seen as attractively priced, with market sentiment positive, allowing Emaar to be more aggressive with pricing. The sukuk is backed by the success of the Dubai Mall, a popular tourist attraction, and has a Baa2 investment grade rating from Moody's Investors Service.

site_title: APS to be used as vehicle to acquire mines
summary: ASIA-PACIFIC Strategic Investments (APS) is set to acquire Coeur Gold Armenia's mines in Armenia through a reverse takeover, with the deal valued at $500 million. The acquisition will be funded by issuing 1.35 billion new shares to GR Business Holdings, which owns 49% of APS. The deal is expected to expand APS into the gold mining sector, with plans to acquire more mines globally. The Armenian government supports the deal, seeing it as a way to develop the country's mining sector and reduce unemployment.

site_title: Tigerair Singapore's May passenger load factor up slightly at 84.9%
summary: Tigerair Singapore reported a 0.9 percentage point year-on-year rise in passenger load factor to 84.9% for May, driven by traffic growth outpacing capacity injections. Revenue passenger kilometres rose 17.2% and available seat km grew 16% last month. However, the airline's 12-month passenger load factor fell 5.6 percentage points to 78.4%. In contrast, Indonesia-based Tigerair Mandala saw its passenger load factor dip 0.9 percentage points to 82.2% due to network rationalization. Tiger Airways Holdings reported a full-year loss before tax of $231.6 million and is reviewing its investment in Tigerair Mandala.

site_title: Key stakeholders' sales prompt 'sell' call on UMS
summary: Key stakeholders at UMS Holdings, a semiconductor company, have prompted a downgrade of its stock to "sell" by OSK DMG. Founder and CEO Andy Luong sold 13 million shares at an average of 69 cents, and a major customer, Applied Materials, sold 2.92 million shares at 70 cents. This has raised concerns about the company's sustainability, despite strong financial performance in the past few quarters. OSK DMG has lowered its target price to 47 cents and warned that profitability may not be sustainable in the year ahead.

site_title: The wild side of penny stocks
summary: Interest in penny stocks Asiasons Capital, Blumont Group, and LionGold Corp has surged, with shares more than doubling in June. Blumont shares rose 75% to 6.4 cents, Asiasons shares jumped 45% to 7 cents, and LionGold surged 17% to 10.2 cents. Despite hefty losses and buyouts, the rebound is attributed to the counters' low prices and investors seeking to average down their investment costs. The rally is also driven by the perception that the stocks are "irresistibly cheap" and may not fall further.

site_title: Lockheed eyeing foreign, non-defence orders
summary: Lockheed Martin Corp plans to rely on international and non-defence orders to offset declining US military spending, with Pentagon orders accounting for 61% of overall sales last year. The company expects US defence orders to drop to 50% or lower, with revenues remaining flat this year and next. Lockheed aims to deliver next-generation weapons, expand its international footprint, and develop new technologies for clean water and energy. CEO Marillyn Hewson emphasized the company's focus on diversifying its revenue streams.

site_title: Deeper skills needed to grow financial sector: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that Singapore's financial sector will grow through specialized skills development rather than expanding jobs. The sector has seen a deceleration in job growth, with 5,000 new jobs created in 2013 and 2012, down from 10,000 in 2011 and 2010. With redundancies outpacing new hires, financial institutions are under pressure to consolidate activities, which have higher capital charges. This shift towards specialized skills is expected to drive growth in the sector.

site_title: YCH to develop supply-chain facility in Qingdao
summary: Singapore's YCH Group signed a memorandum of understanding with Qingdao Iron & Steel Group Co Ltd to develop a cutting-edge supply-chain facility in Qingdao, China's Shandong province. The 13.3 ha facility will be built in the Li Cang district and is part of Singapore's efforts to encourage companies to set up shop in the region. The project aims to enhance supply-chain efficiency and support China's growing economy.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's government has released new private housing sites to boost development, despite concerns over oversupply and weaker demand. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for specialized skills in the financial sector to drive growth, as the industry shrinks. China's consumer price index rose to a four-month high of 2.5% in May, easing deflationary concerns. Meanwhile, Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments plans to acquire more gold mines and a local startup accelerator has launched a virtual pre-accelerator program to help founders.

site_title: Piaggio Aero seeks China production partner
summary: Piaggio Aero Industries, a 100-year-old Italian plane manufacturer, is exploring a joint venture with a Chinese state company to produce planes in China. The move follows a trend of smaller aircraft makers partnering with local companies, similar to the automotive industry's model. The business jet market in China is expected to grow, with deliveries potentially reaching 2,400 over the next 20 years, worth $65 billion. This partnership would align with Beijing's plans to establish China as a major aircraft manufacturing base, competing with Airbus and Boeing.

site_title: China ready for final settlement on Indian border dispute
summary: China is ready for a final settlement on its border dispute with India, Foreign Minister Wang Yi said during a visit to New Delhi. China is prepared to invest more in India if trade rules are eased. The two nations aim to prevent territorial disagreements from affecting economic ties. China has made progress on the basics of a boundary agreement, and Wang expressed confidence in reaching a final settlement. The move comes as China asserts its territorial claims in disputed waters off its eastern coastline.

site_title: Tips on dealing with that empty condo
summary: Century 21 CEO Ku Swee Yong warns that vacant properties deteriorate faster due to lack of use. Investors keeping units in newly completed projects empty may miss out on defects rectified by the developer during the one-year defects liability period. Experts advise owners to quickly find tenants or lower capital appreciation expectations and sell the property. National directors at Jones Lang LaSalle and R'ST Research also caution against buying properties with weak attributes, such as proximity to MRT stations, and suggest selling instead of holding onto untenanted properties.

site_title: China consumer prices hit 4-month high of 2.5%
summary: China's consumer price index (CPI) rose to a 4-month high of 2.5% in May, beating market expectations of 2.4%. The increase was driven by a rise in pork prices and a low base effect, with food prices rising 4.1% from a year earlier. The producer price index (PPI) fell 1.4% in May, marking the 27th straight month of decline. The rebound in inflation rate suggests growth has bottomed out and demand has stabilized, but the central bank has ruled out aggressive stimulus measures due to concerns over overcapacity and non-performing loans.

site_title: Canadian fund to invest more of its assets in Asia
summary: The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan (OTPP) plans to increase its investments in Asia, particularly in private markets, with an estimated C$12.5 billion already invested since 1991. The fund aims to accelerate private investments, working with partners to find opportunities, and has set up an office in Hong Kong to deepen partnerships. OTPP CEO Ron Mock emphasizes the importance of Asia in the fund's portfolio growth, citing its long-term investment approach and focus on value investing. The fund's assets total C$140 billion, with a significant allocation to fixed income and real assets.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Chasen Holdings acquired a 30% stake in Amber Digital Solutions. Aspial CEO Koh Wee Seng increased his stake in LCD Global Investments to 13.68%. Heeton Holdings formed a joint venture with Fairmont Investment & Development. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and CGSI downgraded Grab to a 'hold' rating due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, and Tan Teck Long will take over as the new CEO.

site_title: Tug engineers back strike threat at Australia's Port Hedland
summary: Tug boat engineers at Australia's Port Hedland, a top iron ore export port, have backed plans for possible strike action to secure more leave and shorter work hours. The Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers (AIMPE) members approved proposals ranging from 4 to 48 hours of work stoppages, which could halt a quarter of the world's iron ore exports. The tug boats, operated by Teekay Shipping, guide iron ore carriers in and out of the port. The strike could have significant implications for the global iron ore market.

site_title: Crew of S Korean ferry go on trial on various charges
summary: Fifteen South Korean ferry crew members, including Captain Lee Joon-seok, went on trial for charges ranging from negligence to homicide in connection with the sinking of the Sewol ferry in April, which killed over 300 people, mostly children. The crew faces maximum sentences of death, life in prison, or jail terms. Family members of the victims have shown hostility towards the defendants, with some calling them "murderers" and holding signs criticizing their actions. The trial, which began on June 10, is seen as highly publicized and may limit the defendants' ability to present their side of the story.

site_title: No reason to doubt CPF's intentions
summary: The author refutes doubts about the Central Provident Fund (CPF) in Singapore, emphasizing its primary purpose is to meet basic retirement needs. The CPF Board, established in 1955, manages funds to ensure retirees have a secure income stream.
